text:
This is a great recipe, I made minor changes and it tasted great!!! 

CHANGED: zucchini-2ea.,Chicken Broth- 4 cups, No red wine-replaced with White, 1 TBSP of crushed basil in jar instead of fresh, 1 TSP of dried oregano instead of fresh. 
ADDED 2ea.- yellow squash, 1ea.-28oz. can whole tomatoes- no juice just cut up tomatoe in 4 pieces and 5-Red potatoes cut up. 

After everything cooked for about 1 1/2 hours, I then  puree appox. 1/3 of the soup to a thick texture and mixed to back in with the rest.  

MY FAMILY LOVED IT!!!!!!!!!!

text:
I've used this recipe every winter since I found the posting. 
Jaime's recipe is terrific & I've made several changes which make it more appealing to my family.
 I omit green beans & replace them with cannellini beans along with the Red kidney beans. 
 I use lots of fresh spinach and cabbage if I have it.
 Ditalini is our favorite soup pasta, it hold up better than shells.
 We like lots of veggies so I didn't decrease any amounts of carrots, zucchini or celery.
 The first stage of sauteing the aromatic veggies is so important. It is the basis for a terrific soup.
 Thank you, Jaime! This is comfort food at its best.

Fabulous recipe!  I did some substitutions though:  I used potatoes instead of zucchini, and I added white wine instead of red.  I also used italian-crushed tomatoes and only one small can of tomato sauce.  This is a great recipe that can easily be modified to suit both your tastes and whatever you have in the cupboard. text:
I absolutely love soup and read all the great reviews for this soup. It defintely didn't let me down. I did make some minor alterations based on the reviews. I used 5 cloves of garlic, 8 cups of chicken broth (instead of water), and 3/4 cup red wine, and the whole bag of baby spinach. I didn't add the kidney beans until the last 10 minutes so they wouldn't fall apart. I cooked the pasta separately and then added it. I used more then a half a cup because I like to see the pasta in my soup. It was a very thick soup even with the addition of all that chicken broth. I cooked it for about 1 hour give or take a little bit. I did think that addition of the parmesan cheese gave the soup great taste. I highly recommend this soup. All the great reviews are right, this soup is great.

text:
This was the best soup I have ever made!  I did make a few changes.  First of all, I omitted the celery.  I used 5 cans of chicken broth, 2 cans of tomato paste, 1 can of tomato juice and 1 can of V8. Even with this much liquid I still needed to add the 2 cups of water. I used all fresh vegetables.  I substituted a squash for one of the zucchini.  I also added 1 cup shredded cabbage and 3 red potatoes.  Instead of the seashell pasta I choice Ditalini because I prefer a smaller pasta.  I did not have fresh basil or oregano on hand so I used Italian seasoning.  I cooked it for 2 hours adding the potatoes and pasta in the last 20 minutes.  This does make a ton of soup so you could freeze half and save it for another night.

text:
What a fantastic soup!  And yes, it does make a *ton*.  I cut the recipe in half, and still had a very large pot of soup.  I've never been able to resist meddling, so I also cut down the amount of celery, used yellow squash and zucchini both, white beans instead of kidney beans, and ditalini pasta instead of shells.  Fresh basil and rosemary added wonderful flavor, this is the perfect vegetable soup.  I also added a few drops of lemon juice while it simmered, to freshen the flavors a little.  Thank you Jamie!

text:
This really is a GREAT recipe.  I made it for after Christmas when we didn't need any more calories.  I made my noodles (mini - egg bow ties) in a seperate pot and added them per individual, topped off with a small amount of fresh parmesan cheese.  I didn't add the spinach, and I did use 1- 14 oz. can - Italian diced tomatoes, and only 1 -8oz. can of tomato sauce, frozen green beans, and 3 cups 98% fat free chicken broth, 1 cup of water, and only FRESH herbs. Served with homemade fresh bread! EXCELLENT!!  I also made it ahead of time so it reduced time in the kitchen during the holidays.

This was fantastic! I changed a few things here and there just because of what I had on hand.  I used canned cannelli beans rather than kidney beans.  I used a mixture of chicken broth and vegetable broth, replaced some of the tomato sauce with diced tomato. I added a squash in lieu of 2 of the zucchini and I added some red pepper flakes that gave it a bit of a bite.

My entire family enjoyed it and I have some in the freezer for cold winter nights.

Thanks for sharing this Jamie!

text:
If using tomato sauce it is more a tomato soup with vegetables than minestrone soup.  I replaced a 1/2 cup of the tomato sauce with water and used fresh green beans, adding another 1/2 cup water because the canned beans were undrained.  Three zucchini was a lot to add, switching to 1 zucchini and other family favorite vegetables recommended (corn adds color variation).  If the broth is too acidic or tangy after 10 minutes of simmering add an 1/8 tsp. baking soda to cut it.

Display Name:
mhurst86

city:

region:

country:

text:
This soup really is fantastic! I was craving a hearty vegtable soup, one that I could make during the day, and serve my family for dinner. This is it! The vegtables were all cooked perfectly, and you can really tweak it for your own taste. I added pasta the meatballs (premade) to my husbands dinner, but I just enjoy the soup itself. Some changes I made- I had no fresh herbs on hand, so I used all dried, an "italin" blend, and some additional parsely and bay leaf. I also added a few grinds of lemon pepper. I used carrots, celery (stalks and leaves) canned kidney beans, white beans, and canned green beans. I didn't have any zuchinni, so I cut 3 small potatoes and used those (with skins). I used one can of beef broth and one can of chicken, instead of water( forgot the wine too!). All low sodium... I think that any changes you make will be great! The base recipe is wonderful also, but we made do with what was on hand. For a final touch, I splashed in some worshirtire sauce. Probably not typical, but it gives the soup a richness and brings everything together.


Few quick tips- saute the onions, then add the garlic. Onions need more time to soften, and garlic burns rather quickly. And chopping all those veggies really doesn't take more than 5 mins tops. I saw a few complaints about that-what do you expect? Fresh food takes alitte work!

text:
Amazing soup!  I made very few adjustments in ingredients to match my personal taste.  This one's definitely a make again - Bravo Jamie!

I just want to point out that because so many canned ingredients are being used here, a serving of this soup and a can (which is regarded as approximately 2 servings) of Progresso Minestrone soup are not too far off.  True, making it at home allows us to include a lot more vegetables than the canned soup, but let's not fall under the illusion that this version of Minestrone is so much healthier than we can find in a can.

Calories:
Serving of Jamie's soup - 232
Can of Progresso - 220

Total Fat:
Serving of Jamie's soup - 8.3g
Can of Progresso - 4g

Saturated Fat:
Serving of Jamie's soup - 1.4g
Can of Progresso - 1g

Sodium:
Serving of Jamie's soup - 1267mg
Can of Progresso - 1920mg

Carbs:
Serving of Jamie's soup - 32.1g
Can of Progresso - 38g

Sugars:
Serving of Jamie's soup - 12.1g
Can of Progresso - 4g

I'm still a fan of this recipe, and I think that the benefits of having the chunky fresh vegetables in the soup outweigh the higher sugar and fat content by a longshot, but some people on restrictive diets may not agree.

This is a great recipe! The first time I made this, I gave it 3 stars because the oregano taste was too strong-MY FAULT!!! It turns out that 1 tablespoon of fresh herbs is the same as 1 teaspoon dried herbs!!! I'm so glad I figured it out, since this is so yummy and healthy!

This soup was really good.  I did use all broth and no water as well.  I used regular spinach vs baby spinach (as it was half the cost).  I just chopped it up smaller, and it worked just fine.  I would definately recommend cooking the pasta separately just before serving.  I cooked mine separately, but added it to the soup a few hours before serving, and it soaked up a lot of the juice.  I think doing as the recipes says would work much better.

text:
I was pleasantly surprised with this one!  I followed the recipe pretty closely, though I did choose to omit celery (hate it), use frozen green beans in lieu of canned, and use all chicken broth rather than some water.  This came together fairly quickly and easily and made for a great lunch on an icy winter day.  I was being lazy (and had planned to freeze some soup) so I chose to use ancient de peep for pasta and simply added it towards the end of simmering.  Next time (and there will be a next time) I will add another can of kidney beans and perhaps another bean for a little more texture and protein.  Thanks, Jamie, for a "keeper"!

Excellent!  Even my hubby (who thinks that soup is an appetizer and not a meal) LOVED IT! After reading some of the reviews, I did make a few minor changes to the recipe.  I used fresh green beans (instead of canned), added in 1 cup of shredded cabage, usded 6 cups of broth and 1 cup of water, no salt added tomato sauce, dried herbs instead of fresh, and 1 cup of uncooked ditalini (cooked separately).  I cooked the soup for about 3 hours on low.  This made an enormous amount of soup, which I divided into individual portions and put in the freezer for easy lunches.  YUMMO!

text:
This soup turned out fantastic. Here are my modifications:

1. I did not put in the can of green beans.
2. For convenience sake, I used 1 29 oz. can of tomato sauce, 2 14 oz. cans of chicken broth, and 1 cup of water instead of the amounts listed. 
3. At the very end, I felt like it was missing something, so I added a bit of cayenne pepper. That made a huge difference!

This is a really hearty, delicious soup. I would like to have a bit more broth next time, so I'm going to increase the liquids when I make this soup again. My entire family loved this recipe!

text:
Good foundational recipe that can be customized per individual tastes.  I increase the garlic and use a mixture of dried herbs because I rarely have fresh on hand.  Also, I use canned stewed tomatoes (broken into small pieces--with the liquid) and a few tablespoons of tomato paste instead of tomato sauce and use only broth instead of water and broth (also works well with a combination of chicken and beef broth).  For my taste, this does need some added salt, but that's just me.  Enjoy!

text:
I got 2# of zucchini in my CSA delivery this week, so was looking for recipes to use it in when I came across this one.  I started with about a pound of sweet italian sausage; after browning and draining the oil, I continued pretty much with the recipe, with only the following changes:  probably a bit more zucchini (so I didn't have to save a portion of one), doubled the broth, added a pinch of red pepper flakes, used kale instead of spinach (also from this week's delivery), used the full can of beans, so probably 1 1/2 c.,  and dried herbs instead of the fresh.  Oh - no wine (forgot!).  I liked the idea of cooking the pasta separately, as we have lots of soup left over, and I know how pasta absorbs most of the liquid.  I let people grate their own parmesan.  (I am sure that this would be great without the sausage - it was a request of my husband, and it really did turn out good.  Everyone at the table gave it 2 thumbs up!)  Thanks for a great starting point.

text:
This soup is really good! A couple changes - definitely add at least one can of garbanzo beans (balances the "bite" of the wine/spinach); Saute the carrot/onion/celery mixture until the carrots are soft (mine stayed too firm for a couple days); Add the beans during last 20 minutes to prevent mushiness. I found that I needed more liquid, so I tossed in a very small can of tomato sauce and some sugar, as well as an additional 2 c. of chicken stock and another 1/4 c. of wine. I will make this all the time!

text:
This soup is OUTSTANDING!! I followed others' suggestions to substitute diced tomatoes for part of the tomato sauce and added the kidney beans toward the end. I added more red wine than the recipe indicates -- don't know what difference that made. Definitely cook the pasta separately  and spoon soup over it to serve. I simmered for about 2 1/2 hours. I will make this over and over again -- we loved it!
P.S. On making a second time, I added shredded cooked chicken breasts (3 medium sized breasts) -- made it a bit heartier, same delicious, satisfying flavors.

I too ommitted the water and used 4 cups of chicken broth. I did not use green beans but a can each of cannelini and garbanzo beans as well as the kidney beans. I also tossed in a can of diced potatoes.

I used more vegetables than the recipe called for but I love hearty soup. I also used merlot wine (not cooking wine) and not only did my kitchen smell fabulous, the soup is wonderful. You really can add any veggies you like.

I don't eat meat but my family does so I will be adding italian sausage to theres. I need not look any further for a good minestrone soup recipe.

text:
This soup was incredible. I was looking for a soup to make on Halloween after trick-or-treating. I have never been too crazy about minestrone, but I had to try this one after seeing the ratings and reviews. I am so glad that I did! My husband, in-laws and even my 2 year old absolutely loved this minestrone soup! I took some of the advice from other reviews - added a little more red wine, used a can of diced tomatoes, put the beans in later in the cooking time, and served sweet italian sausage on the side (I cooked it separately, sliced it, put it on the soup after ladling it into the bowls, and then topped it with parmesan cheese). It does make a lot, but the leftovers are just as wonderful if not better the next day!

None
text:
Best soup I've ever made, and soup is my specialty! It was so good I finally got over it being sad it was still soup weather in May. I did this to make it vegetarian, healthier & richer: Skip the chicken broth, add one can of garbanzo beans, 2 cups cooked quinoa, and 1.5 cups cooked red lentils. I did NOT add pasta. It didn't need it and it would have made the whole process more complicated and harder to store. I also just added some tomato paste (1/3 cup of so) instead of tomato sauce to save money.
I felt amazing after eating it! (Full disclosure I finished the whole pot in 48 hours).

city:

country:

text:
YUM! Just made this soup for lunch. I have been craving some good soup for days, but haven't had the energy to make it as I have not been feeling well. What is it about being sick that makes us crave soup? Comfort that's what and the canned stuff just doesn't do it for me. Anyhow, I decided that my craving for soup outweighed my not feeling well and got up and made it. It wasn't alot of work at all, totaly worth it! I cut the recipe in half as other reviewers went on about how much it makes. Glad I did as there is just my hubby and myself. I followed the recipe almost exactly. The only things I changed was to add a can of diced tomatoes with liquid, used half zuchinni and half yellow squash, used frozen italian green beans, and I added 1/2 t of ceyenne pepper to open up my stuffy head.  I also used pam instead of olive oil to cut the fat. This soup is wonderful, thick hearty and brimming with fresh veggies. The ceyenne was a nice touch and did open up my head. My picky hubby even liked it despite the fact that he doesn't like spinach or squash ;)
Would be great served with salad and crusty bread too!

I followed the directions right on except that I did not have fresh basil/oregano so I used the dried spice-aisle kind. I browsed another Minestrone recipe on this site (Minestrone Soup 1) and it uses 1 can stewed tomatoes and a 1 tbsp of tomato paste, that sounds much more sensible.

text:
The only thing I changed with this recipe was I used all broth (4-5 cups), no water.
I also didn't have fresh herbs (with the exception of a few leaves of fresh basil, which I saved, minced and sprinkled on top when serving)... instead I used a heaping teaspoon of dried oregano and almost exactly 1 tablespoon of dried basil. Which seemed adequate in flavoring the soup nicely.
I only had 1 1/2 cups of tomato sauce, so I made up for the rest by chopping up 4 roma tomatoes that I had that needed using.
This was so good and made a whole lot of soup. After 5 people ate and 3 having seconds, there was still half a pot left!!! Can't wait for leftovers!

Added some "no salt" to give it a bit of salty flavour.  Brings sodium content down using 1tbsp parm cheese.  Now you can seconds or if your my husband 3rds and not feel guilty.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
What a delicious, healthy and hearty soup! Made some slight changes -  I used a can of white kidney beans, omitted the green beans and spinach. The amount of vegetables can be adjusted to your liking. I only had one 398ml can of tomato sauce so I used that plus a 798ml can of diced tomatoes. I used 4 cups of water with 4 tsps of chicken bouillon and omitted the wine. I also added a heaping tbsp of white sugar to cut down on the tartness and added 1 tsp of hot pepper flakes. To make it even more hearty, I tossed in tortellini instead of the seashell pasta. I served with French bread. So delicious! This makes A LOT of soup. I'm sure it will freeze well though! Will make again!

text:
oh my gosh, this is the best minestrone I have had!  This sure beats the canned kind any day!  I made a few last minute adjustments. (I was going to make homemade chicken soup, but forgot to buy chicken!!  LOL)  I used 4 cups of beef broth, a lg. can of crushed tomoatoes, parsley flakes, thyme and garlic powder.  I also added one HUGE potato, omitted the zuchinni, and added a can of whole kernel corn.  Oh and it was a little too tomatoey for me, so I added a can of chicken broth (I was out of beef).  And it turned out GREAT!!  Thank you Jamie for a wonderful recipe to warm me up on these cold Wisconsin nights!!

text:
If you love vegetables, you will love this soup.  It is a great healthy comfort food.  I DEFINITELY recommend not combining the noodles with the vegetables before serving or when putting up the leftovers.  The pasta will absorb all the juice.  I served the soup over the pasta, but when I went to put the leftovers in the fridge, I mixed it all together in the same storage container.  Don't do this.  The pasta absorbs all the soup.
Thanks for a great recipe.

text:
Luscious! So healthy! A complete meal in one pot. I chopped the veggies in my chopper. I cooked it longer than stated. I also added 3 new potatoes because my hubbie doesn’t think any meal is complete without potatoes. Also, as Justin Wilson used to say, this is a great soup to clean out the fridge! I didn’t have fresh herbs. That’s my next goal . . . to grow a herb garden (too expensive at the local mart). My chicken broth was roasted garlic. Thanks so much for sharing!!! As stated cook noodles only when you need them. This way you don't have soggy noodles (or noodles that soak up broth)mixed in as the last reviewer complained about.

text:
I a lot of chopping to do, but this soup is very good.  I substituted potatoes instead of zuchinni.  I cut up the potatoes and boiled them for about 10 minutes and then added it to the soup. I don't think I will do this next time and just let it cook longer or in the crock pot.   I also just added the noddles right into the soup, without cooking them first.  The soup was a little thick because of the starch from the potatoes so next time I will add more water or chicken stock. Instead of using all tomato sauce I used i can of garlic and onion diced tomatoes.  Overall very good and healthy recipe.  Makes a ton!

text:
This soup was easy and wonderful. I'm a high school student, and although it was a busy schoolnight, I went to Safeway and bought ingredients so I could eat this! I ended up adding canned spinach, and half tomato sauce/half diced canned tomato, and omitted carrots. I used organic vegetable stock. I forgot to buy pasta, so left it out, but the soup was hearty enough to make a fine dinner. My family loved it, even my mom who had a stomachache ate seconds! Next time, though, I'll add more green beans and spinach, cut down on zuchinni, and add more diced tomatoes instead of sauce. I'll leave out kidney beans until the last 10 minutes or so of cooking because my kidney beans were so mushed up that they were nowhere to be found.

city:

None
text:
This soup was really delicious. The entire recipe makes a lot of soup - I cut it in half and it made 6 servings. The other changes I made were: 1) twice the garlic, 2) a little less carrot (2 for a half recipe), 3) 1/4 c. wine for a half recipe,  4) I substitued dry for fresh herbs (make sure to adjust measurements - 1 tsp. dried oregano for 1 Tbsp. fresh, 1/2 Tbsp. dried basil for 1 Tbsp. fresh), 5) I left out the spinach, because I didn't have any, and the green beans, because I don't like them. I came out with a hearty, flavorful, and truly delicious soup that adds a lot to any meal! I highly recommend this recipe.

userID:
845422
Display Name:
PRAY_54

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674133.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This soup is pretty good!  My family sure enjoyed it!  A few things to note, though, before you begin: 

1) Two things make this soup: the parmesan cheese and the flavor.  The parmesan adds a lot of unexpected taste to the whole picture, so do not skip over it.  Regarding the flavor, go ahead and simmer the collaboration for 1.5-2 hours minimum.  Then, throw it in the refrigerator overnight.  The flavors will pull through much better… trust me. 

2)Change of ingredients: I nixed the spinach, because I’m not a big fan, threw in a bunch of halved button mushrooms and about ½ cup of diced yellow pepper (sauté both of these in the very beginning with the onion).  Furthermore, grocery stores sell seasoned tomato sauce.  I used ½ “garlic and onion” tomato sauce and half regular to bump the recipe up a notch. 

3) Existing ingredients: Use only two zucchinis and I wouldn’t say more than two carrots, especially if you add the mushrooms above.  Otherwise you’ll lose the broth in a mass of vegetables.  Be generous with the oregano and basil.  And don’t be afraid of the wine - it adds a beautiful flavor. 

4) Possibilities: I considered adding Italian sausage to the recipe, but served those on the side (-*highly recommended*).  Shrimp might be interesting, though I haven’t tried it. 

Enjoy! You can have a lot of fun with this soup!

text:
This does make lot, which I like a lot!  It freezes well and it's great to have on hand in the freezer.  I've made this a few times.  Yesterday, I followed the recipe exactly, give or take veggie amounts.  I had been using more chicken broth and less tomato sauce.  I find that using tomato sauce with the chicken broth in these amounts makes this soup more filling and satisfying as a complete meal.  Also, I see no need to saute veggies, or add olive oil (or salt) to this recipe. I've done it both ways and there was no difference in taste.  I love this soup, and the parmesean really seals it as a five star.  Thanks Jamie.

I was searching for a GREAT Minestrone recipe when I stumbled onto Jamie's version.  It had some different ingredients than others I'd looked at, the red wine and tomato sauce in particular, and I think it was these differences that made this soup so extraordinarily good.  As I've tried to move toward a more healthy and nutritious diet, I've often been disappointed at the lack of flavor in many "healthy" dishes, but this minestrone soup has more flavor than I thought possible.  Definitely worth the time to make, and I'll never crack open a CAN of Minestrone again.

It was great.  The only thing I would change is to use fresh ingredients wherever you can.  I used fresh green beans and the flavor was better.  If you are trying to cut down on sodium (which is what the author stated she was trying to do), avoid the canned stuff, which has lots of salt in it.  If you must use canned beans, rinse them first so some of the excess sodium comes off.  Overall I did enjoy this.  I added fresh basil, fresh thyme.

Absolutely AMAZING!! My husband and 12 year old will not eat: kidney beans, celery, tomatoes (unless puréed in spaghetti), spinach or zucchini and they LOVED this soup! Followed recipe with no changes, scooped out 1/2 for me and puréed the rest. Thanks Jaimie....my family all ate vegetables and loved them for the 1st time ever!

text:
With some minor adjustments, this is the best vegetable soup I've ever had! I've made it many times and still love it. I don't like kidney beans and didn't want green beans in this soup, so I use yellow squash instead and add more spinach. I replace the water with 2 c. of vegetable broth. I skip the red wine, pasta and parmesan. I also add the carrots sooner to make sure they end up tender. Using Trader Joe's organic tomato sauce is a must for me too, as I think the flavor is great. Thank you so much for this recipe!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Before this even had a chance to simmer, I tasted the broth so I could start thinking about what I might need to add to enhance the flavor... to my surprise, it was already delicious! No measuring for me. And I hate having a measely 1/2cup or so of beans hanging around, so I tossed in the whole can. I just realized I didn't add the green beans...oops! I would've done frozen if I added them anyways. --My *ONLY* criticism, something I should've trusted my instinct on, was the carrots. I knew I should've either chopped them smaller or cooked them longer. I ended up letting this simmer for awhile longer to cook the carrots more. Since I had already added the pasta at that point, the pasta ended up a little too soft... bummer! The flavor is so irresistable I found myself sampling the bowls I had portioned out for lunches... mmm! Looking forward to lunch tomorrow!  **Tip: add the dried pasta toward the end of simmering and you can skip the extra step of cooking the pasta. Just be careful you don't cook too long!

text:
This soup is delicious especially on a cold day. However, I did a little tweaking here and there to make the recipe even better. I used 2 cups of tomato sauce and 2 cup of dice tomato. Also added additional red wine about 3/4 of a cup. Used white beans in addition to kidney beans, but cut back on zucchinis to just 1(not much of a fan). I also used frozen green beans, chopped up instead of canned. Omitted the onions completely and the recipe was still fine. Also add about 4-5 cups of chopped spinach and a lot more basil, I just love the aroma of basil! I made this for my mom and dad, they both loved it. I recommend this recipe for beginners since its easy to follow.

text:
This recipe is great as written, but I also use it as a base to use up whatever vegetables are in the fridge and whatever canned beans I have in the pantry.  I love to add butter beans and barley! I use vegetable stock as we are vegetarian and I add an extra 1/4 cup of grated parmesan to the pot as I love the creaminess that it gives the soup.  It's a lovely hearty soup, perfect comfort food for winter especially when served with garlic bread. I usually serve it without the pasta on the first night and add pasta the second night for variety. Freezes well.

text:
This recipe is amazing! I took it to an internationals carry-in and every bit was eaten. I did make some changes, primarily using vegetable broth rather than chicken broth in order to make it a vegan dish and I added both garbanzo beans and cannelli beans. I also read the suggestions of others and instead of just zucchini I used squash and potatoes. I used cooking sherry instead of red wine and also added some basalmic vinegar. I also sauteed all my fresh veggies along with the herbs before adding any liquids. The only things I waited to add were the canned items (beans). We had a dietician at the event that looked over the recipe and she was thrilled with the healthiness of it! Great choice for anybody trying to make a large, healthy meal.

userID:
2251623
Display Name:
Jenni Rose
isPro:

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/90425.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was so sooo delicious! It embodies classic minestrone as a comfort food. As usual though, I couldn't help but add my own twist on it and if any of my changes appeal to you please use them! First of all I halved the recipe so my alterations were applied as such: 1 cup can diced tomato in place of 1 cup of tomato sauce, about 1/4 cup chardonnay, juice of 1 lime, splash of red wine vinegar, 8 oz can garbanzo beans in place of green beans, 1 yellow squash in place of 1 zucchini, 1 roasted red bell pepper, 6 oz chicken breast pieces, and I used mini farfalle (bow ties) instead of shells. For more seasoning I added about 2 tbsp sugar and a pinch of each of these: red pepper flakes, cumin, thyme, rosemary, paprika, and 1 bay leaf. I also made parmesean crisps instead of sprinkling it on top. After trying it both ways I think sprinking it on top is indeed better!

text:
Great recipe!  I feel the need to point out the nutrition error in a previous review.  I am a dietician and Jamie's recipe is very healthy. I subbed whole wheat pasta and used low-sodium broth and tomatoes, rinsed the beans before adding to the soup and use fresh or frozen veggies. I don't know where the reviewer got some of the numbers but I just made the soup and can say that the sodium is NO WHERE near 1267 per serving (when using lower sodium products).  Fresh is ALWAYS better than canned and pre-made. Great soup Jamie!

This soup turned out pretty good. I just made a few minor changes... used veggie broth instead of chicken, used white wine instead of red, and used dried oregano and basil (a little fresh basil too). text:
This was delicious for being so healthy! This recipe is very modifiable depending on what you have on hand.  I used 4 cups of stock, 2 cans of diced tomato, & 1/2 cup red wine for the base. I skipped the sauteing step and instead let everything simmer for 1.5 hours.  I threw in an entire box of rotini pasta for the last 20 minutes.  I omitted the green beans and used about 2 cups of canellini beans.  I seasoned with some Tony's Creole seasoning, and then when it was done I added a few dashes of McCormick's Salad Supreme and parmesan cheese.

text:
WOW!!!  This was SOOO good.  To be completely honest, while it was simmering I was getting a little bummed because I didn't think it smelled all that great, but we just got done with dinner and my husband and I both absolutely loved it!!  I already just sat down to write it on a recipe card with a few of my personal preferences.  Definitely a 5-star.  One note: this NEEDS to be topped with the Parmesan.  Without it, it would not have been near as good. It's vital to the perfect flavor.  

My adjustments...I doubled the chicken broth, only did 1 zucchini, but added 1 yellow squash, added 2 cans of Rotel tomatoes and some creole seasoning and cayenne for a kick.  I used dried herbs because that's what I had.  I did not add the wine, simply because I didn't want to buy any today.  I didn't feel like the soup was missing anything without it. Absolutely perfect!    I will make it exactly the same way next time!

text:
Fantastic recipe!  I made a few minor adjustments to the recipe such as, I used garbanzo beans instead of kidney beans.  I also used minced beef in.  I browned the meat in a bit of olive oil and when partially cooked I added the garlic, followed by the carrots and celery.  One minute later I added the onions and let the mixture cook through.  I used two veggie cubes and two chicken cubes instead of chicken stock and I also used one small can of tomoto puree.  I had to add more water since I used meat and since I also added a bit more vegetables than were called for, but that's due to personal liking.  I froze half and will definitely enjoy it in the future!

text:
Great recipe. Even my boyfriend who is strictly anti-vegetarian finished a bowl of this soup! I did make a few adjustments as follows: after simmering for a while the soup did evaporate a little, so I added two additional cups of chicken stock. I also added a 1/4 cup pearl barley about 40 minutes before the soup was ready. Instead of cooking the pasta separately, I simply added the raw pasta in the final 20 minutes of cooking time. Like another reviewer, I thought the high acidity of the tomato puree called for some sugar, and added a tablespoon which seemed to work quite well. Next time I might cut down on the celery (some of it still stayed a little crunchy even though I cooked this for about an hour, but other than that, I wouldn't change anything else. Plus - it makes plenty of soup - I actually had to use two pots! This will definately come in handy stored in containers in the freezer (which is good considering it took so long to prepare...chopping vegetables is time consuming!). Thanks for a great recipe Jamie!

text:
Great soup!  After reading a number of reviews, I did make a few changes.  I used beef broth rather than chicken.  I also added a large veg. bullion cube to the water which I increased to 2 1/2 cups.  Instead of 4 cups tomato sauce I used 2 cans chopped and 1 can sauce.  I also added 4 small white potatoes cut into cubes and 1 lb lean ground beef browned (My Hubby isn't wild about soup with no meat).  I used about 1 C frozen green beans rather than canned and left out the wine because I didn't have any on hand.  Finally I kicked up the spice a bit.  I added twice as much Basil (fresh), 1 T italian seasoning, 4 cloves worth of garlic (minced fresh in a jar), salt, pepper, and a couple of shakes of dried hot peppers just to give it a little kick.  I would say this is the best ministroni soup I have ever made.  It is great because you can easily make changes to fit your own tastes.
Review:

text:
I don't even LIKE minestrone and just made it for fiance, but boy is this a far cry from the canned kind... This is fabulous!  5 star worthy recipe if there ever was one... I only made a couple changes, used all chicken broth in place of water and added an extra can, so 3 cans total, added a can of garbonzo beans, omitted the spinach and used dry basil because my store was out of fresh and added a bay leaf.  This is amazing, I am so glad I tried it!

Added:  I am on Weight Watchers so I wanted to know the serving size... With the extra can of chicken broth I used, it made a little over 12 cups of soup.

text:
This soup is wonderful.  I have been looking for a recipe for a great minestrone and this one hit it right on the nose.  I too made it with vegetable broth, I addded a few bay leaves for extra flavor, and used white wine (about 1/2 C) instead of red.  It's easy to taylor to your preferences.  This soup freezes well if you leave the noodles out.  I also made it with barley on one occasion and that was great too.  I make this soup about once a month and it never gets old.  Thanks for the great recipe!!!

"BUONO MINESTRA"  Good Soup in Italian! I've been looking for a good minestrone and this is it! I pretty much stuck to the recipe but I did add more broth and I added cannoli beans. About the last 10-15 minutes of cooking, I added a couple handfuls of pasta (pick your own shape) and some Romano cheese and it was Delicious. Will definately make this a staple. What a savings too. It's almost a sin to buy canned soup. A small can of minestrone runs over a dollar a can some almost two and doesn't taste half as good. Buon Appetito!

text:
Jamie's Minestrone is absolutely magnificent!! The soup is bursting with flavor and chocked-full of healthy and tasty veggies. Some of the things I did differently were substituting some canned green bean and bean water for plain water, doubling the amount of broth, and using diced tomatoes instead of tomato sauce. I also added some dried rosemary and thyme as well as the basil and oregano, which were also dried. This turned out perfect!! Definitely a keeper! Thanks Jamie!

city:

None
text:
This recipe is simply terrific. I read all the reviews first and made a few of the suggested changes (doubled the amount of broth, added diced canned tomatoes instead of the tomato sauce, added red chili peppers for a little more kick, added some canned corn, added some chopped scallions I had left over in the fridge). Also, since everyone was saying how much it made, I split the recipe into two pots keeping one vegetarian and the other half I added spicy italian sausage to (as my husband would shy away from anything that was totally veggie). I also omitted the pasta and didn't miss it at all. The soup was so good I couldn't help sharing it with friends and family- but then I didn't end up with much for me! I'll be making it again this weekend and probably doubling the whole thing so that I'll have enough to eat for lunch all next week. Yum, yum, yum!!! Thank you Jamie :-)

text:
Very good. I halved the recipe, which still made a huge pot, and made similar adjustments as other reviewers: diced tomatoes and a small can of sauce, all broth no water, white beans, more pasta and left out canned green beans. Good combination of veggies and simmer time is right on for a thick soup and tender veggies, with the exception of the celery which I will sauté longer next time. Cooking pasta separate and adding to each bowl really helps keep it from being overdone. Great with Parmesan and French bread - thank you!

text:
My husband claims to hate half the vegetables in this soup, but cleaned his bowl with a smile on his face. I managed to burn my garlic right off the bat so threw that out and started over, subbing 3/4 tsp garlic powder when I poured in the liquids. Used dried herbs (on hand). "Pepper to taste" was 1/4 tsp (perfect). I did not add salt and it didn't need it, even though I used homemade chicken stock with very little salt. I would probably add if I didn't use canned green beans. Very, very good!

country:
None
text:
So yum!!! As the author says, this is a low sodium, high vegetable version of minestrone. My modifications to the recipe were: 2 cups of crushed tomatoes, 4 cups of water, chicken bullion to make 2 cups of broth, and because I happened to have a 14 oz can of tomatoes seasoned with basil, they went in too. I was a little shy on some of the vegetables but that didn't really matter. I also used probably 2 tablespoons of my favorite Italian seasoning blend instead of fresh. I didn't have red wine on hand so I used 1/4 cup of balsamic vinegar. The tip to cook the pasta separately and add it in the bowl is excellent. This is a great use-it-up soup and it's also freezer friendly. It's going to get a long term place in my recipe rotation.

text:
This is my "go-to" soup.  Easy to make, eaten by all in the family including the picky eaters.  A couple of changes: I use 2 cans of chicken broth (Swanson low-sodium)with a 1/2 can water and 1/2 can red wine instead of the measurements listed.  I also make 1 1/2 cups (dry) shells and add them directly to the pot after they are cooked.  This time I used whole wheat shells and they were fantastic!

text:
Incredible, I've tried a few different recipes, and this one is by far the best. I've never made it exactly as stated, which to me says that you can't go wrong. The very few negative reviews sound to be people who aren't used to cooking - anyone who knows anything about cooking knows that tomato sauce is basically passata with herbs and garlic, and maybe some tomato puree. It's not dolmio, and it certainly isn't ketchup. I just use my own tomato sauce ingredients and throw them in the pot - for this recipe, that's lots of dry herbs, lots of garlic, a bay leaf and three tins of plum tomatoes that I squeeze to break up. I also added two dry chillies. My boyfriend just had two extra helpings of this. Absolutely top notch, good enough for us to eat for three days in a row

Really enjoyed this soup.  Great flavors and loads of veggies.  Per other reviews I used 4 cups chicken stock, 3 cups tomato sauce, 1 can diced tomatoes, added in 3 cubed red potatoes, used 2 zucchinis instead of 3, added 1 can (not 1 cup) kidney beans and cannellini beans, and used dried oregano and basil. text:
I stayed pretty much on course with the recipe with the following exceptions due to personal taste:
-I cooked up some hot italian sausage first and sauteed the mirepoix with that.
-We don't like green beans so I substituted shredded cabbage there.
-I'm not a fan of the kidney bean so I used garbanzos insted.
-I prefer dittelini in this particular soup.
-We require a high level of spiciness so I added cayenne and crushed red.

This is a total keeper. I cut the recipe in half for the two of us and it still made a TON so bear that in mind.

text:
This was delicious! I used 1 14 oz can of crushed tomatoes, and 1 14 oz can of tomato sauce, instead of all tomato sauce. I also used swiss chard in place  of the spinach because I had it on hand. 

This is the first minestrone recipe I have encountered that recommends cooking the pasta separately - excellent idea.  For leftovers, I didn't add the cooked pasta in until the soup was completely cool. This prevents the pasta from becoming monstrous ginormo noodles overnight as happens too often.

Considering adding some bacon or pancetta in at the beginning with the onions next time.

text:
Great soup. Only changes I made were based on financial need (or using what I already had bought). No celery, but 2 cans of beans (one kidney, one cannelini). Probably a few extra carrots because the 2lb bag I bought had The Smallest Carrots Ever, so after cutting up 6 or so it seemed like too few, and I ended up putting in all 2lbs! I swear it did NOT look like that much... I used a whole package of baby spinach - it cooks down so it barely adds any mass. I also used 5 cups water + 3 chicken bouillon cubes, and instead of 4C tomato sauce, I had v8 in the fridge so I used 4C of that. The only other thing I added was 2 cans of stewed tomatoes and a can of tomato paste because I was worried about leaving out the tomato sauce. I only had dried spices too, no fresh. Finally, I cooked a whole 16oz package of small shell macaroni and mixed it in at the end. I know this sounds like a lot of changes but ultimately I still love this recipe. I will be happy to make it with fresh spices when I can afford them. I just happened to have wine on hand, and I always use bullion cubes when I can... Even the night I made it, the soup was chunky and delicious. If I had extra tomato sauce instead of v8 I would have used it, but still a whole bag of macaroni because I love pasta and chunky soup. Exactly the recipe I was looking for... from one Jamie to another, thank you! :)

text:
I've made this dozens of times, and it usually turns out good.  Normally, I use only two zucchini and 1 handful of raw baby spinach, and trust me, that's more than enough.  (That change resulted in my 4 star rating for the original recipe.)  Recently I made this, and tried using veggie broth to make it more vegetarian friendly.  If you're going to do this, do NOT skip the wine, and plan on adding tons more spies than called for (at least 4x each of oregano and basil).  You lose a lot of flavor when using veggie broth.

text:
I have never lover of minestrone basically because I'm not a fan of tomato based soups but there was something about this recipe that caught my eye. 
My husband is a soup fanatic and I try to find good recipes that will last for a few meals because I get home too late from work to start fussing in the kitchen.
I have to say that this is a fantastic recipe for something I'm not even crazy about!
I pretty much followed it as written but I added a can of diced tomatoes and baked some Italian sausage in which I cut in to tiny pieces and threw into the pot. Also, I only used two zucchinis because they were pretty big ones and omitted the wine simply because I really dislike it. As usual, I tasted a bit here and there as it cooked but I just had my first bowl and could not believe how incredibly scrumptious this is.
It's the very first minestrone that I've loved. I can't recommend it highly enough. Jamie, you're a genius.  Thank you sooooo much!!!

text:
Amazing soup!  I halved the recipe and substituted chicken broth for the water, and diced tomatoes for half the tomato sauce.  I kept the amount of garlic the same (3 cloves)  Also added 1/2 tsp salt and grated pepper to lightly cover the top of the pot while cooking.  I actually made it up to the point of putting all the veggies in and bringing it to a boil then turning it off for the afternoon.  When I got home,  Insimmered it for about 20 min with the kidney beans in and  cooking the pasta on the side.  It was perfect!  My husband wanted another batch the next night and I couldn't agree more!  A healthy and tasty way of getting all your veggies!

text:
Yum!! This soup is delicious, healthy, hearty easy. I changed it by adding potatoes & chickpeas and left out spinach & greenbeans. Used 1 tbsp dried basil and 1 tsp dried oregano as I had no fresh. Used all veggie broth instead of water. Lots more noodles as I like noodles! Added kidney beans at the end so they weren't all mushy. Also added some chipotle poweder, which made all the difference! Blended maybe 1/4-1/3 for great texture! 40 min is perfect or I feel the zucc, potatoes, carrots, etc... would get mushy. Glad I will be eating this for days!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This soup is SOOO good!  A great way to get the kids to eat a variety of veggies!  I made a few changes to suit my family's taste...

I omitted the red wine (but I'm sure it's really good with, I was just worried the kids wouldn't like it)
I omitted the pasta
I omitted the parmesan cheese
I used 1/2 large vidalia onion instead of 2 whole onions
I added vegetable stock instead of chicken stock
I added 1 idaho potato ( I peeled, cubed and boiled it to texture I like and added it after the soup was done cooking)
I also added peas and corn, about 3/4 to 1 cup of each
The only other thing I did different was I waited until the last 5 minutes of cooking to add the zucchini so it didn't get mushy, it was perfection!  I cold eat this soup every day of the week!

text:
I really enjoyed this soup!  Great taste and very satisfying with all the veggies.  The one change I made to this recipe was that I cooked it in a slow cooker.  I sauteed the garlic and onions in olive oil, threw that with everything else (except pasta and cheese) in a slow cooker and cooked on low for somewhere between 6-8 hrs.  I boiled the pasta separately and added it to the soup before serving.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614261.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Homemade soups are super nourishing.   This is a great recipe.   May I make a few suggestions? keep celery in.  It's a wonderful, mild diuretic. keep zucchini also.  Green beans:  fresh are best. simply wash an cut into 1" angled pieces.. so easy. Homemade chicken broth... a good habit to get into making a big batch once a week.   preferably use a can of organic chopped tomatos (juice is optional) and can of organic beans, unsalted (your choice)  for greens lacinata kale is superb as well as endive.... as for pasta,  it's best to add at end of cooking soup.  Turn off heat,   throw in handful of raw pasta and let sit about 8 mins. Pasta should always be "al dente"  Otherwise if overcooked,  it spikes insulin levels rapidly. wine would be optional... I would increase fresh chick broth instead and finally, of course,  fresh grated parm cheese.   Yummmm !

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Comforting and yummy! Every other time I've tried to make minestrone it seems to be lacking - this has everything you could want with wonderful full-body taste! I followed other reviewers and used white wine since we didn't have red. I also sauteed the onions in the olive oil before adding the garlic and veggies. One mistake a novice chef might make is accidently burning the garlic which can completely ruin this delicious soup! If you cook the onions through first then you won't risk burning your garlic. I also used garbanzo beans, and added about 1/2 the can on juice from my canned green beans (they're my fav). You cannot mess this up! Can't wait to make again once the weather cools down so I can thoroughly enjoy Jamie's Minestrone!

Display Name:
MINDY1315

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614284.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is the best minestrone soup I've ever tasted, and my family agrees.  I used to really like the minestrone at Olive Garden, but this is even better.  After reading the reviews, I made a few changes too...  I used 2 cups chicken broth and 2 cups vegetable broth (no water).  I used 1 cup of noodles.  I like a few more noodles than the recipe calls for but not too many that the soup is dominated by them.  I used 2 zucchini and 1 yellow squash just for color.  I used 2 cups frozen cut green beans instead of canned.  I found that I was out of oregano so I used a heaping tablespoon of dried italian seasoning.  I used the entire 15 oz. can of kidney beans.  I added the wine - first 1/4 cup to see how it changed the flavor, then the other 1/4 cup because it was delicious.  It added a depth to the flavors.  Oh, and one more thing - I added a 15 oz. can of fire roasted diced tomatoes.  I like tomatoes in the soup.  It was so delicious!

text:
Delish!  Made this yesterday and  was very pleased with the results.  The changes I made were:  Used 5 cups tomato sauce cause I had a half can leftover from another meal.  Used frozen green beans and I yellow squash for one of the zucchinis.  I added a can of diced tomatoes per other reviewers.  Used dried spices because that is what I had on hand.  Added a handful of ditalini pasta to the pot last 10 mins of cooking and added the can of kidney beans at the end.  I also added a package of fully cooked "al fresco" spicy jalapeno chicken sausage, skin removed cut into 1/2 inch slices.  Also added a pinch of sugar because I like to do that when I cook with tomato base sauces.  This is a very hearty dish.

text:
Absolutely delicious! I have been wanting to try a minestrone recipe for awhile, & I am so glad I picked this one! It is a bit time-consuming to chop all the vegetables, but I would say it is well worth the effort. I ended up adding more chicken broth & tomato sauce, simply because I added extra kidney beans & some cannellini beans, & I like a lot of juice in my soup. I also used dried basil & oregano with good results. Because of my additions, we ended up with tons of leftovers (not a bad thing! :)) This is a very hearty & filling recipe, but very healthy. A new favorite!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674139.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Best minestrone recipe I've found!  I've made this many, many times and my family is always happy when they find out it's on the menu.  I play around with ingredients, depending on what I happen to have on hand.  Canned italian green beans work in a pinch, and I use arugula rather than spinach.  It's key to cook your pasta separately and only add as you dish it out.  When storing leftovers, don't add the pasta to the soup - it lets the pasta break down and then you have mush.  Also, if I add beans, I always add them near the last 20-30 minutes so they don't get mushy.

text:
Wonderful! I was a little worried it would be bland, because I do love my spices and heat, but it was just lovely as written (though nearly anything can benefit from a bit of sriracha!). One thing to plan for is using way more liquid than called for - so perhaps buy some extra stock and an extra can of tomato sauce. The red wine really gave a subtle but necessary depth of flavor, so I recommend using it. This is the first veggie soup I've ever made, and it made my day! Thanks for sharing what will become my go-to cold-weather soup!

text:
I had my doubts while I was cooking this, but this soup turned out FABULOUS.  I didn't have the issues others did with it being too thick, either.  *Changes*  I used  1 can tomato paste + 1 1/2 cans of water per cup of tomato sauce called for.  I also subbed potato for zucchini since I sadly had none.  I also used white wine instead of red, added an extra can of kidney beans and omitted the green beans. Like another user, I did not use pasta.  I might add some in for my husband if he wants it so it's more hearty.  Otherwise I followed the directions and ended up with a HUGE but wonderful batch of Minestrone.  This puts Olive garden on a run for it's money!

text:
Very delicious!  I used the bones of this recipe to make my own version: substituted extra can of chicken broth for water and cabbage for spinach, added can of navy beans, diced potatos, and one chopped tomato.  Also added 1/2 cup parmesan/romano to the pot.  Didn't have fresh herbs so I used 1 tsp Italian seasoning.

This recipe is great! I make it as-is and even my meat-loving hubby who thinks it's not a "meal" unless meat is the main course will happily eat it for dinner with a side of toasted garlic french bread. text:
I thought this was an excellent recipe.  I didn't go exactly by the recipe but the taste of the broth is the base and then you just do whatever you want as far as adding veggies.  I put chicken broth, vegetable broth (instead of plain water), stewed Italian tomatoes (instead of sauce), onion, and seasonings adding more garlic in my slow cooker, let it cook all day long to marry the seasonings.  Last two hours of cooking I added some frozen mix with carrots, etc. Let that heat through, added couple cans of beans then the last hour added some pasta.  Turned out superb except hubby did mention he would prefer more broth but that is easy to fix.  Great meal we had served with grilled toast points.

text:
I am sure that there are other excellent minestrone recipes at this site, but I finally chose this one and it did indeed live up to all the expectations! I did make it a day ahead due to my schedule, and yes, it is better the second day!  I added quite a bit more broth and a little more red wine.  Next time I am going to add the kidney beans much later in the simmering or even on the second day because they were quite mushy (the green beans were fine).  I also added some Italian sausage that I had cut into small slices and then browned, and that added some good flavor and pleases the carnivores.  I also added garbanzo beans which I love.  Next time I will add a little more of the herbs and garlic, just for kicks, and I may add some chopped canned tomatoes.  It worked out so well that I am gong to serve it for a dinner party this Sunday.  Thanks! (P.S. Except for the sodium, which you can reduce with low-sodium or homemade broth and by rinsing the canned veggies, this is a very healthful soup!  Lots of fiber, low fat, and many vitamins and anti-oxidants and lycopenes.)

city:

country:

text:
This soup is very yummie tomato based soup.  I added 1 shot of Worcestishire sauce like other reviewers mentioned and it spiced it up, excellent idea.  Since I did not want to eat it with pasta, I just added 2 cubed smaller potatoes into it after the liquid came to a boil and I used veggie broth instead of chicken to keep it 100% vegetarian. I cooked it for 1 hour after all ingredients were in there but the carrots and the celery could have cooked longer.  They were eatable but had a slight crunch to them. Maybe next time I have to chop them into smaller cubes. I also cooked it on medium low after boiling because I just wanted it to get done faster.  I think if I cooked it for 1.5 hours it would have been perfect.  Next time I will add the parmesan cheese at the end.  This soup uses up a big pot and I definitely will have to freeze a lot of it, but that's ok, at least I don't have to make it from scrach for a while.  I highly recommend this soup.  Enjoy!

This recipe is great.  I omitted the pasta and added a can of diced tomatoes with basil and oregano.  I think I will add more chicken or vegetable broth next time because it was very thick.  One important thing I found was that the cooking time was not nearly long enough.  I simmered the soup about 2 hours rather than 30-40 minutes.  My vegetables were not near cooked after 30 minutes.  My family loved this soup - I will definitely make it again!

country:

text:
Add me to the list of another cook more than satisfied with this minestrone recipe. For such simple ingredients it turns out delicious and smells SO good while simmering on the stove. I used 2-15oz and 1-8oz cans of tomato sauce and 1- 29oz can of diced tomatoes, about 3 1/2 cups of chicken broth and 1 1/2 cups of water. It took awhile for my carrots and celery to cook down so they weren't so crunchy even with sauting them first but that's because I didn't slice them real thin. The longer cooking time only made for an even better tasting soup! I didn't use the wine only because I didn't have any but will try it next time just to compare.  Also used dried oregano and basil for lack of having fresh and it tasted great, I can only imagine how good the fresh must be.  I used a can of cannelini beans, drained and rinsed, in place of the green beans. All the other ingredients stayed the same as the original recipe. We're so happy we've got leftovers of this delicious minestrone!  Thanks much for sharing this great recipe Jamie!

Display Name:
cblwolf

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3044037.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
YUM!! These five star ratings are right on! I doubled the recipe to bring some to a friend and really didn't need to double it. I nearly overflowed my pressure cooker with the doubled recipe! I have an 8 quart electric pressure cooker and started this recipe (with the lid off) on brown rice, to sauté the onions and garlic until they were soft. Then added everything else besides the pasta, green beans, and spinach and set it for the soup function (16 minutes). I quick-released the pressure and added the pasta (I used ditalini). I used manual pressure cook time of 4 minutes, once again quick-released the pressure and added the green beans and spinach. Gave it a minute or two for the spinach to wilt and it was complete! The Parmesan finish is a must!! Delicious!

text:
I love this soup. It's my #1 WW recipe for 2 points or less. I usually use 1 28oz can of tomatoes and a small tomato paste. That's usually what I have on hand. It doesn't change the outcome.  I also add a tbsp of hot pepper flakes as a personal preference. The parm cheese is a must!  Thanks for a quick and easy, healthy recipe.  I make it often.

My hubby doesn't like soup, especially any soup without meat in it, and he dubbed this the best minestrone soup he's ever had!  I only used 1 onion and left out the zucchini, as I didn't have any on hand, and it was so good!  Super easy to put together and then let simmer as I baked up a fresh loaf of bread to serve with it.  I love having the noodles separate so they didn't get soggy.  Don't know why I haven't thought of that before!  Thanks for the amazing recipe!!!

text:
This hit the spot! Here are my adjustments: 1 can petite diced tomatoes and one can of tomato sauce with one large box of low sodium vegetable stock. I also used cabbage instead of spinach because it seems more traditional to me. And I used white cannelini or great northern beans. The beans should be white IMHO. I also added a rind of parmesean Reggiano to add a bit more depth. And I didn't have fresh oregano or basil so I used dried. Just be sure to add them to the oil after sautéing onions. This helps with the flavor. I added celery too. Was celery called for? Anyway, it's perfect. I love this so much!! I use cavatapi noodles which are hearty and fun. Thanks for the great recipe!

text:
Fantastic! I used a combination of many of the suggestions that together turned out to make one of the best soups we've tried: I used about 46 oz. of chicken broth, no water, 2 cups of tomato sauce, about 3/4 cup of wine (half when the recipe tells you to and half near the end). I used dried spices, but probably ended up using about the same quantities of the dried that the recipe calls for in fresh. Otherwise this might be bland. I also added a pinch of crushed red pepper, not to make it hot, but rather to bring out the flavors. oh, and I chose not to use any kind of bean other than the green.

Display Name:
Becky
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674152.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've made this recipe a couple of times and it's delicious! Yesterday I followed it almost to the letter, except I made it in the slow cooker. I first sauteed the onion, celery and carrots as directed. I added the garlic closer to the end of sauteeing, instead of the beginning, since garlic can burn easily. Then I dumped this mixture into the slow cooker along with all the remaining ingredients except for the spinach and the pasta, and let it cook for about 4 hours. I used vegetable broth to make it vegan. I added the spinach near serving time and let it wilt. Pasta is cooked separately, because if you cook it with the soup, it will suck up all the broth. I used small whole wheat shells and it was delicious. This recipe is very adaptable. You can use whatever veggies you have on hand. It makes an excellent and healthy vegetarian meal served with some whole grain garlic bread and maybe a salad.

city:

country:
None
text:
This was great!  I made it for my 9 yr. old who loves minestrone.  I usually don't care for it, but this recipe was so delicious.  I used 3 c. tomato sauce, 2 c. chicken broth, and 3 c. water (to further reduce the sodium a bit), and it was very flavorful still.  I used canellini (white kidney) beans and extra zucchini in place of green beans.  A recipe like this leaves room for substitutions, IMHO.  I didn't have red wine, so I didn't use it.  I also used less olive oil in a non-stick pan to lower the calorie count.  If you serve 8 with this recipe, they will be very large servings.  I thought it could serve 16 if you had bread and salad or something similar.  I froze some, so hopefully it will defrost well.  I'll update how that goes when I get around to using it.

text:
This was an amazing soup!!! I altered the recipe slightly and added 4 cups of chicken broth and 1 cup of water (to cut down the taste of the tomato, and thin the soup. I also added a can of chili beans with 1/2 teaspoon of chili powder to give it more of a kick. Since i did not have fresh oregano, i used 1 tablespoon of dried oregano. I even added a couple of potatoes. My whole family enjoyed this soup, and in fact i am enjoying a bowl of it as i am typing. my helpful tip would be to make sure you cut the potato and zucchini into small pieces (you do not want them to be too big). Overall this was a delicious soup and i will make this again and again.  Thanks Jamie!!!

city:

country:
None
text:
Delicious!  As with other reviewers, I added more garlic (we love it, so I added a lot to our taste).  For the liquid, I ended up adding a total of 4 cups of chicken broth, a cup of veggie broth that I had and a cup of water and I replaced one cup of sauce for diced tomatoes undrained.  Without the extra liquid, it would have been much more of a thick stew than a brothy soup.  I also skipped the pasta and just had it as a tomato based vegetable soup.  Oh, one last thing...I only added the spinach for the last 10 minutes of simmering.  I think longer than that would have been too much for the delicate baby spinach leaves.

This recipe makes a LOT of soup.  Be prepared to cut the recipe down or have lots of leftovers.  I put some in the freezer for another day! :)

This ministrone has a great flavor. I was forced to adapt the recipe slightly as i felt the ration of tomatoe sauce:water:chicken broth was slightly high for my taste (reduced tomatoe sauce by 1 cup and water by 1/2 cup). For vegtarians the chicken broth can be substitued by a mushroom broth without any affect on the taste. 

Jaime, congratulations and thanks, there is nothing better than a well presented and tasteful recipe!

text:
This is a great recipe!  A few suggestions though - I used fresh cooked beans, not canned; I used frozen green beans, not canned; I left out the zucchini (don't like it, thought it'd be mushy anyway); and I added chickpeas (a must for minestrone!).  These changes made for a great soup!  In general, this is a great starter recipe, but the proportions of the veggies can be adjusted to your preferences.  I also used minced garlic and dried herbs instead of the fresh --- still turned out great!

This went over really well with my family.  5 out of 6 approved!!

Changes Made:  Omitted the water and used a 48oz carton of broth.  Otherwise there would not be enough liquid.  I also upped the pasta to 1 cup - ditalini not shells, could have probably used a little bit more but it wasn't lacking.  We just like a lot of pasta.

Next time will add corn, use 1/2 the zucchini called for and add some potatoes.  Personal preference but tastes great with the veggies called for.

Perfect flavor and makes enough for 12 with second and possibly third servings.

text:
Jamie, this rocks!  I, too, like almost everyone else, made slight modifications -- but not many.  I have a childhood aversion to cooked zucchini, so substituted one good-sized, peeled russet potato per the suggestion of another reviewer.  Simmered everything for closer to two hours and then covered, reduced heat and simmered for another two hours.  You're absolutely right:  the longer it simmers, the better it tasted.  Totally skipped steps 3 and 4; there's enough soup to feed 10 easily without the pasta.  Had it this morning for breakfast (couldn't help myself, the devil made me do it -- couldn't have it yesterday when I made it so this was the first time tasting) -- absolutely wonderful!  The flavors blend so beautifully; there's a certain sweetness that I'm thinking is the tomato sauce and the fresh basil.  I'll be passing this recipe along to a gluten-free friend of mine (without the pasta it's perfect) and to a couple of vegan friends.  The only thing they have to change is the broth.  Great recipe -- thank you so very much!  This is going to be winter necessity.

text:
Loved this recipe.  Next time I will chop everything first before starting to cook.  I used 3 tsps of fresh minced garlic, 32 oz chicken broth, 4 cups of water, only 1- 28 oz can of tomato sauce, no wine, white kidney beans - which I added after a 1/2 hour of simmering, no spinach, a bag of frozen green beans and added cooked ground hamburger.  I let simmer for 2 hours on low and added the noodles right before serving.  I warmed it up for lunch and the noodles were perfect the next day.  Even my husband loved it...and he doesn't care for zucchini!

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
This is a great, versatile base recipe!  I make it multiple times per year.  I usually make a large batch and freeze the leftovers.  It freezes beautifully as long as you skip the zucchini and spinach (it gets mushy).  Also, when freezing, I make sure not to include the pasta, because that gets mushy as well.  Instead of spinach and zucchini, i use cabbage.  Add balsamic when serving.  I use whatever beans I have in my pantry.  I will also use whatever tomato product I have in my pantry.  Fresh is always best, but I usually use dried basil and oregano.  Finally, I don't use any water, all low sodium stock and wine.

text:
The end result is delicious, but only after some modifications.
First of all, I used about 35oz (1000g) of canned tomatoes instead of the sauce. I also used frozen spinach (250g), which in the finished soup I found to be kind of odd and out of place, even though it adds more nutritional value. I also used frozen green beans, and veggie stock instead of chicken.
I had to use *way* more water than called for. I think altogether it was about 1.5 liters (1.5 quarts), in addition to the broth. I have no idea how only 2 cups water plus the broth would be enough given the quantity of vegetables in the soup. Since I added more water, I also added more basil and oregano.

Overall this is a delicious soup. It makes a lot, so I am going to freeze about half of it.

Display Name:
Michelle Roth-Kiva

city:

country:
None
text:
Hello fellow reviewers! Made this for dinner tonight. I must admit, I enjoyed this more than my fiance did (but that doesn't surprise me...). Having said that, I do think I like Andrea's Pasta Fagioli a bit better.... It only took reading thru one page of reviews (sorted by most helpful) to realize only "slight" changes were necessary. The only modifications I felt were critical (some out of necessity) were to add the rind from a block of Parmesan cheese to my soup (it would have gone to waste otherwise, and to my surprise, gave my soup GREAT flavor) and to substitute garbanzo beans for kidney beans, Italian-seasoned tomato sauce for plain tomato sauce and chicken stock for broth . I chose to add wine (cabernet sauvignon) and am glad I dd. The wine adds flavor and depth, IMHO. Despite other's complaints about not having enough broth, I had plenty. :) And, despite one reviewer's complaint about this being less healthy than Progresso....It really depends on whether or not you use low-sodium / salt-free products (I used reduced-sodium canned green beans / stock and no salt added tomato sauce) & if you RINSE / DRAIN your beans. These two changes can AND do make all the difference. Served with warm slices of parmesan focaccia bread (Sandra Bennett), this was a perfect meal for this chilly fall evening.  And, to boot, I got my serving's worth of veggies for the day! Thanks for sharing,  Jamie! :-)

text:
Cold winter night? This is the perfect dinner! Here are a few modifications, but this is the kind of thing you can create to taste. Here's what made it perfect for me: used large can of crushed tomatoes with basil + 3 cans chicken broth and no water. Used red potatoes (2) and no celery or green beans. Also used both kidney and white beans -- and it looked gorgeous. I saw one review that added potatoes at the end because of a longer cooking time. I threw the potatoes in withthat carrots though atthe beginning and it was great. Near the end, also recommend adding a little olive oil to the pot just to add more depth and when serving, definitely top with a generous spoon of Parmesan. I served with Parmesan crescent rolls and it was a cozy monster hit!!!

text:
Wow, I can't believe so many people rated this 5 stars! My version was only slightly tweaked--no beans (didn't have any kidneys on hand), frozen spinach instead of fresh, less tomato sauce. Turned out so bland! Hearty, though, which was nice. Definitely more like a veggie stew than soup. Also, as stated, the soup yields WAY more than 8 servings--maybe closer to 16 or 20 servings. Next time, I'd reduce the amount of servings, as well.  If I make this another time, I will triple the spices, quadruple the garlic, add more broth, and probably cook for longer. I only let the soup stew for 1.5 hours, so maybe the flavors hadn't had a chance to fully meld or something. Overall, kind of a let down--I'm going to keep searching for a minestrone recipe that suits my tastes.

text:
This is a wonderful, no fail soup recipe.  I agree with the other raters, you can customize it to your family's liking.  If you don't like something, leave it out.  If you really need something else, then add it.  There are so many wonderful flavors in this soup, an addition or subtraction will only make it better for your personal taste.  I made it exactly as written and also more customized with extra carrots, a few potatoes and a can of chopped tomatos instead of tomato sauce.  I also used lots of spices and herbs, it was a great dish to pour the 'end of the bottle' for many herbs and spices. Thanks for sharing, the whole family loved it.

text:
I made this soup today for my family that came to visit for the day.  It was DELICIOUS! Because one person was vegan - I changed the chicken broth to just water with a few tablespoons of salted herbes (a product I get from Gaspe in my province of Quebec). I also used a 28 oz. tin of chopped tomatoes, about 1/2 cup of tomato sauce that I had hanging around that was only going to go to waste.  I liked adding the pasta individually to the bowls rather then the usual method of dumping the pasta into the soup pot.  When I served the soup, I put a good dollop of pesto sauce on the top.  My nephew said this really made the soup by putting this on top (he had 2 servings).  He now wants the recipe!  I'll definitely pass this one on to anyone who wants a simple but tasty soup - and being a Type 1 diabetic - low in carbs!! Guess what I'm having for dinner?  FatCatAnna

text:
I just made this with my wife tonight and it came out great.  We used cannellini beans instead of kidney beans and we used 4 cups of chicken broth instead of using water (although we did add ~1cup of water as well).  We skipped the green beans and added dried herbs (didn't have fresh on hand) and we skipped the red wine (didn't have any on hand, will try with red wine next time).  For pasta we used ditalini and we used finely shredded mozzarella instead of parmesan.  This recipe is definitely a keeper (just alter vegetable to your liking).  If relevant, we used Hunt's Tomato Sauce which was lower in sodium compared to the other cans.

This recipe hardly needs another review, but it was truly that wonderful!  I made this for the first visit by the future in-laws (particularly for my fiance's super-picky father) and it was a huge hit with everyone.  I did make the following changes for various dietary and other reasons: 1 cup white wine for the red, no beans other than green, no pasta -- used potatoes, no spinach -- used cabbage, added bay leaves and parm. cheese rind, increased stock by quite a bit and used more of the called for spices, and made it one day in advance, which definitely seemed to improve the flavor.  Thanks so much for this recipe!

This is one of those soups that you can totally change to your family's taste without sacrificing the awesomeness of the soup.  My family doesn't like celery or green beans so we omitted them, added fresh tomatoes, 2 boxes of stock one chicken, one beef (accidentally thought it was chicken), 15 oz can of tomato sauce, 2 yellow squash, 4 huge cloves of garlic, dried oregano and basil, ditalini pasta, 1/2lb of ground beef and a whole can of kidney beans.  I love spinach in soup but the kids won't eat anything leafy green in their soup so I left it out.  I will definitely be making this again really soon.

text:
Excellent soup and very easy!  I added one can of stewed tomatoes and the water, instead of one of the cups of water called for.  The only question I had is why a recipe that calls for fresh ingredients recommends canned green beans.  If fresh veggies are not available, substitute frozen since they are so much better for you and don't have all of the sodium.  I'm not sure it's necessary to cook the veggies and pasta separately.  If you're going to simmer the soup for a while, you can toss everything together and they will all cook in the pot.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My fiance declared this minestrone 'better than Olive Garden's'.  And I agree!  What I did differently:  crushed tomatoes for tomato sauce; fresh green beans; much more spinach (stemmed and chopped coarse, even tho I did use 'baby'); just two zucchini; ditalini pasta.  What I will do differently next time:  blanch the green beans; use one zucchini (even two was *plenty* for us); maybe another can of beans; maybe a can of whole tomatoes, broken up.  I think keeping the pasta separate is key!  I used the ditalini based on another reviewer's suggestion that ditalini holds up better in soups.  I did make a second batch using red beans and didn't care for them much.  They were smaller and mushier than the kidney beans.  And one more note on the prep time:  maybe I'm slow, but I spent an hour preparing the vegetables; much more than the thirty-five minutes indicated on the recipe.  But, I did stem and chop the spinach and also used the fresh green beans.  But the end result was well worth it!

text:
LOVE THIS RECIPE! Nothing needs to be changed unless you have a preference. It is excellant with the addition of the wine and parmasan cheese - don't leave these out. Only because I wanted to I used fresh green beans and did add more spinach, used 4 c. chicken broth (low sodium/low fat) and added water as needed to adjust consistency of stock. I used 2 c. no salt tomato sauce so I could better control sodium levels and sub'd cauliflower for zucchini because I don't care for zucchini. This is easy to make, doesn't need to cook long, makes a lot and is a GREAT soup that is adaptable to your personal taste. Thanks Jamie for sharing this with us.

Display Name:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/155162.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I had a bunch of spare veggies on hand and needed a recipe to put them into - something fairly flexible so that I could make substitutions as needed. This recipe was perfect! It's nutritious, makes a ton, and surprisingly filling - one bowl with some crusty bread and I was stuffed! I definitely didn't use all the ingredients listed - for example I omitted the red wine and spinach, and added zucchini. I also used crushed tomatoes rather than tomato sauce, and used Ditalini pasta. That's the beauty of this recipe - use what you have, or what is in season, or what you love. And, you can feel good about eating it! Thanks for the keeper :)

I sauted the veggies in the big pot that I used to make the soup, and at the end I just put the pasta right in with everyting else and let it cook there. I used all homemade veggie broth up front instead of the water called for. But aas it kept cooking I did need to add quit a bit of water, in order for this to have any broth. with as much veggies as it has in it. Great recipe!

text:
I've made this about 3 times so far, each with a bit of tweaking.  I find that I get the best flavor if I omit 2 cups of the tomato sauce and use 2 cups of V-8 juice instead.  I also added a can of drain portabello mushrooms to the soup while it was simmering.  I only had white wine on hand, so that's what i used.  I also used 1lb of browned ground beef instead of pasta.  My husband loved it.  Anything that sticks to your ribs is a winner with him.  Plus, most of these veggies I got out of my veggie garden!  Perfect!  I served this in bread bowls and got rave reviews.  There was not one drop of soup left.   5 Stars!!
