text:
This IS minestrone soup.  Classic minestrone is a vegetable soup except for maybe stock - many here have meat...How Italian it tastes depends a lot on your touch with the spices (enough, but not too much).  I don't use kidney beans, I do use a lot of mushrooms.  I'll make the sofrito and maybe some veggies in broth and use an in-the-pot blender to make a heartier base, into which the chunkier veggies go to cook.  This is the stuff, right here.  Use all fresh ingredients, if you can.

text:
Though I made a couple of changes, I am still rating this recipe 5 stars, because I think it would still be yummy without my changes. I made those because of what was available in my pantry.  First of all, I dint use chicken broth, I used vegetable, and used the full amount (instead of the water too). Then I dint have tomato sauce, so I used 4 fresh tomatoes and 3 tablespoons tomato paste. I also used chick peas instead of the kidney beans and I doubled the spinach. Lastly I added a couple of shitake mushrooms, and lots of crushed red pepper to suit my husband's spicy tastebuds. It was just tooooooo yum!
Thanks for sharing such a wonderful recipe!

I made this for our family tradition of  meatless mondays.
I left out the spinach and zucchini, and instead of using 4 cups of tomato sauce, I used 2C sauce and 2C diced canned tomatoes instead. I had some mini macaroni noodles that I used in place of the shell pasta and used dried herbs that I had on hand
My family liked it with the exception of my 9 year old who I have a hard time getting to eat his veggies. 
My husband placed a biscuit in the bottom of his bowl pouring the soup on top. 
Will make again in the future.

city:

country:
None
text:
THanks for such a great recipe. This soup is in my winter rotation, and it is great for all those things in your fridge I lovingly call "must goes" I have made many variations, based on what I had on hand. My favorite is to start with a puree of leftover French Onion Soup (from this site) and add to it beef broth (leftover from prime rib) and whatever veggies I have on hand. I always use the whole wheat shell pasta, and I always cook it in water and let it sit for at least an hour (do not drain) before I add it to the soup, in order to keep the noodles from soaking up all the broth. I like to add the carrots and celery early, and the zucchini and spinach towards the end. A great, healthy meal for families on the go! Thanks, Jamie!!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Update below! This recipe made a hearty dinner for two and we froze 4 quarts of soup for later.  Used a mix of crushed tomatoes and diced instead of the tomato sauce, doubled the spices, and left out the spinach (I forgot to buy any).  Used elbow macaroni instead of shells; shells would have been prettier, but I already had elbow in the cupboard. I let this simmer on the stove for about three hours before adding the pasta and serving.

2015 update - This has become my go-to vegetable soup recipe. Sometimes I make it as written, but after the base of aromatics and tomato, there's a lot of flexibility to go in any direction. I often omit the pasta and I've swapped vegetable stock for chicken to make a dinner for vegetarian friends. I tend to use marsala as my cooking wine.

I often make a pot and freeze it in single-serving containers for lunches.  It's a good, hearty, healthy meal without the added sugar, salt, and preservatives of canned soup. (Plus, I don't feel so guilty if dinner skimps on vegetables when we've had a big bowl of veggies for lunch!)

I have made this more times than I can count and I have never heard a complaint!  The only changes I make are:  frozen green beans (or fresh if available)and I used Italian-crushed tomatoes and only a little can of tomato sauce.  I make either a loaf of tomato bread or crusty country bread to go with it -- it is GREAT!!!!  Always a hit.  This the best minestrone I have ever had; I can never eat minestrone at restaurants now.  I prefer to make my own.  Oh, it is EASY to cut up stuff and get it all ready ahead of time so the actual puttting it together can go quickly!

reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674136.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This really is more like a stew than a soup with the amount of broth & water the recipe suggests so I had to add more water in order to make it an actual soup.  There are way too many vegetables in this and it's a lot of working chopping everything up by hand (no food processor).  I think there was a bit too much tomato sauce and would use more chicken broth next time.  Also, it needed a lot of salt & pepper because it is basically a very bland, vegetable soup.  The parmesan cheese makes an excellent touch and definitely makes for a lovely presentation.  

I also didn't think there was enough pasta so I added more, because afterall, that's what minestrone soup is...pasta, beans & veg in a tomato based broth.
Review:
Rating:
5

text:
This is my first attempt at a minestrone, and it was a success!  It ended up a little too thick, so I'll have to address that next time with more liquid.  I did let this simmer for 60 minutes as I felt this let the zucchini and carrots soften a little more.  I included the red wine (an $8 merlot...nothing expensive).  My wife and I both enjoyed this recipe and would recommend it to all!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
5+++!!! This was one of the first allrecipes.com recipes I ever made; hub & I made this together when we were dating a few years ago, and I never rated it.  It is SUCH a great soup and such a great base to take it as far as you want. I made a vegetable stock, from scratch, because I have so many garden veggies to use, and subbed that for the chicken broth & water. Ended up with so much stock that I doubled the recipe. Used fresh green beans, omitted the spinach and used fresh corn on the cob, along with some additional Trader Joe's frozen fire-roasted corn. Subbed 2 med cans diced tomatoes, 1 small can tomato sauce for the 4c tomato sauce. Doubled the pasta 'cause I'm a carb freak. Served with a dollop of homemade basil pesto which was absolutely the BEST final touch to the soup!  Served with homemade rolls. Great dinner for a chilly autumn night. FABulous soup. Thanks SO much, Jamie!

text:
turned out WONDERFUL!!  my fiance and i love soups...and this one made it in the recipe box for sure!  I made a couple of changes though.  I doubled the amount of chicken stock..and i'm glad i did!  i did 1 yellow squash and 1 zuch.  i also added 1 can of diced tomatoes (italian flavor/style) - - may add one more next time!!  I also did not have the fresh herbs..i used dried and A LOT.  Turned out great...but will try fresh next time.  DO NOT LEAVE OUT THE PARMESAN!!  this is a must have... i tried the soup (forgetting about the parmesan) and it was "missing something" - added the parmesan and that was IT!! mmm.  I also did not add the wine (was delicious without) - but my fiance added just a few spashes of merlot at the end when simmering. MMM..was very very good!  I ate mine with saltine crackers..mmmm.  can't wait to have the leftovers tomorrow!  it's a keeper!

text:
Everyone I have served this soup to has loved it!  We always double the recipe – it is great to pack up and take for lunch.  I add some diced tomatoes and skip the spinach, but other than that stay pretty close to the original.  Also I use ditilini pasta instead (sometimes called salad macaroni) because that is the type of pasta in the minestrone at the Italian restaurant I worked at.  I think it works a little better in a soup than the seashells.  Delicious!

I was not formerly a fan of minestone, but this soup was a big hit.  I borrowed some of the ideas of others.  I substituted vegetarian broth for the chicken broth. userID:
615195
Display Name:
Aspiring Chef Rita
isPro:
False
followersCount:
52
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
744
favoritesCount:
1699
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/146.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I'm giving this a five even though I agree with so many others - this is not a "soup" its almost vegetable stew.  Thankfully for others reviewers who said that I decided to trust them.  I used the suggested amt. of onions and celery, only used 2 lg. carrots, omitted the zuchinni and pasta (just a preference).  Used 4 cups of chicken broth (rather than 1/2 water, l/2 broth), used a 32 oz. can of whole tomatoes in thick puree breaking up the tomoatoes, 1 8 oz. can of tomato sauce, the kidney beans, splash of wine (not really necessary), and all the seasonings.  During the last 15 min. I added a cup of diced potatoes and last 5 min. added the can of green beans (can't imagine cooking canned green beans more than 5 min. - they turn to mush!).  It was delicious - but do want to say that even by my cutting back that much on the vegetables there is not a great amount of liquid.  We did love it though - the seasonings were just right and it tasted like minestrone.

text:
This was very yummy... I made a few changes though... I used 4 cups beef broth instead of chicken, 1 can tomatoe sauce, 3 tablespoons tomatoe paste, 1 can of drained diced tomatoes, no spinach and a little over 1 cup of wine.  Oregano and basil was dried instead of fresh, and I used penne pasta.  Next time I would add more kidney beans because I really like them.  Yummy!  I just hope I remember all the changes I made for next time...

text:
This recipe was great! This is the first soup I'd ever made, and I got raving reviews from my 5 housemates. Made a few alterations due to what I had on hand - used 3 cups sauce and one tin of crushed tomatoes, used frozen green beans, used a 3 bean mix instead of kidney beans, added just under a quarter of a cabbage. I made this the night before serving, and simmered it for about 2 hours - hence I also added more water. The results were fantastic! Served with "Bread Machine Rolls" and fresh butter - will definitely be making this again! Thanks Jamie :)

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Thank you, Jamie, for this great tasting, simple recipe!!
I discovered this excellent recipe on here years ago. I have recommended Jamie's Minestrone Soup to strangers for  almost 10 years now. I have taken her basic recipe and made some minor modifications. I try to use all organic ingredients, when possible. I add an extra can of red kidney beans.
For convenience, I use a frozen organic Mediterranean Blend of veggies from Whole Foods, which contains almost everything I need. For extra protein and Vitamin B12, I'll bake a half (or whole) chicken breast, cut it up, and add it to the soup. I NEVER cook or ADD the pasta to the soup directly! I always refrigerate the left over soup and pasta separately. Some good grated Reggiano Parmesano on top is the "icing on the cake". P.S. I strongly recommend using cannelloni beans, NOT a substitute.

Display Name:
CheddarIsBetter

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677176.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
For this, I believe I end up making a larger portion than the recipe says (have a really big pot that I always make when I make it).  I love garlic and always add a great deal more than this recipe ever calls for.  You can substitute 1 heaping tsp of basil and oregano, as fresh is more expensive / doesn't keep long......also lets you have them on hand in the future and for other cooking.

I also tend to use cannelini beans rather than the kidney, since so much is already red in here lol.  I wait to add the spinach after I bring the pot to a boil, which causes spinach to wilt quickly that lets you cram a whole bunch in.  I end up buying 2 lbs, and I often will add any remaining spinach to the leftovers over time.

Lastly, if you buy everything "normal" (meaning not the unsalted varieties) you will probably still end up with less sodium in the end product.  However, I get everything "no salt added."  You will not miss the salt.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
If I'm making an all vegetable/ pasta soup, I don't want to use chicken broth in it.  I change that every time & use vegetable broth instead. I pretty much followed the rest of the recipe,  although I used a little more or a little less of some of the ingredients- depending on what I had on hand- it is fairly close. I did add a can of diced tomatoes & more green beans then called for & used already sliced carrots, so I'm not sure how many there are. I just dumped it all in. I don't think 30-40 minutes is enough cook time,  so it simmered much longer. Keeping the pasta separate doesn't work for me because I plan on freezing several containers for my evenings when I don't want to cook, so after cooking pasta separately,  it's added to the pot too. I'm hoping my non-vegetarian husband will like it too! I will make it again, even if it's just for me.

text:
Blackeye Peas, Fresh Butternut Squash, Fresh Green Beans !

This soup was excellent! Hearty and full of flavor. I was looking for a recipe that seemed forgiving so that I could make substitutions based on what ingredients I had on hand. I included everything the recipe called for with these substitutions/modifications: 

1 yellow onion + 1/2 white onion; 1/2 c chopped celery; roughly half of a fresh butternut squash peeled and cubed in lieu of carrots; cab for the red wine; 1 can blackeye peas in lieu of kidney beans; 1 large handful fresh green beans that I then chopped into 3rds; dried oregano and basil in lieu of fresh (remember to adjust accordingly - general ratio is 1:3 dried to fresh). Simmered just under an hour until squash and green beans were tender.

Cooked spiral pasta separately (al dente) then added to pot of soup just before serving.

Topped with fresh grated parmesan and sprinkling of capers.
------------------------------
For those few minority reviews that complained it was too tomatoey - perhaps they mistook "cups" for "cans?" For example, 4 cups tomato sauce is really just two of the standard 14.5 oz cans, and 2 cups broth is just one can. (It's soup - the ounces don't have to be exact! ;) )

5

text:
This minestrone is by far the best I have ever eaten! The only ways I varied from the recipe as written were to add a couple  small diced garden tomatoes that needed used and since I didn't have red wine, I added a few splashes of balsamic vinegar, salted each layer as I went since I was using unsalted chicken stock, added a sprig of fresh rosemary, and omitted the parmesan rind (sprinkled grated parmesan on in each bowl instead). I am not a huge fan of beans so I pureed the beans and broth--didn't taste them or have to deal with the texture I hate, they just effectively disappeared. I loved the fact this came together relatively quickly and used ingredients that are mostly staples.

It makes a ton - so great for food prepping! I love that you can throw all kinds of veggies in it. 
I used 4 cups chicken broth. Instead of just spinach I used a spinach/chard/kale mix and added an extra cup of it. Onion powder instead of chopped onion worked fine. I threw in some salt but honestly, due to the extra broth, it didn't need it. 
The soup is hearty, delicious, and simple! A PERFECT winter soup.

text:
We love Minestrone ! And I know like most soups, it's very forgiving.. I had made as is before and it was too "tomatoy" for my taste. So this time, I only used 2/3 the amount of tomato sauce called for and extra broth to make up for the missing liquid. I skipped the wine. I didn't have any zucchini so substituted some bell peppers. Also dried herbs for fresh, about 1/3 the amount, as dried herbs are stronger than fresh.
It was delicious and we enjoyed it for lunch with some crusty bread.

I've made this twice. The first time without the zucchini (I completely forgot. The second with the zucchini. Both time it was a huge success. My mother-in-law, who can be difficult to please, LOVED it.  She actually asked me to make it again. Once the veggies are cut, the recipe is a breeze. Perfect for the cold weather. It has the flavor of a soup that's been cooking all day without  it taking all day.  I didn't use the red wine and I think I might add another cup of water next time to thin out the the tomato soup a bit.  Overall, a filling, healthy soup!

Loved the soup.  I did make a few modifications, 1) used 4 cups low sodium chicken broth and one cup water, 2) 2 cans of beans (cannellini  and kidney beans), 3) entire batch of fresh oregano and basil I got from the store, probably 4-5 TBSP each, 4) 1/4 TBSP of cayenne pepper, 5) mixed in some orzo into the soup, no pasta shells, 6) did not use spinach or the green beans as my pot was not big enough and would have boiled over!, 7) no wine, 8) and used diced tomatoes instead of tomato sauce.

685208
Display Name:
KIM624

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674139.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I cannot review the recipe as written because I didn't make it as written, but as a starting base, this was excellent. 

Instead of chicken broth & water, I added four cups of vegetable  broth to make this an entirely vegetarian dish. I also cut the serving sizes most of the vegetables in half since several of the comments mentioned that this recipe makes a ton. It still made a lot even with cutting things in half. I omitted the wine and used two cups of tomato sauce with a 15 oz. can of diced tomatoes (with the sauce) in place of the four cups of tomato sauce. I don't like the texture of zucchini, especially cooked, so I diced a medium potato and added that instead. I used frozen green beans instead of canned since I find they hold up better in soups and stews. Lastly, I substituted 3/4 cups of ditalini pasta for the shells. 

One things many of the comments mentioned, which I did not do, was add extra broth. Between the pasta and adding potatoes, all of my liquid was soaked up. I will probably add eight cups of veggie broth next time. 

I served it with some freshly made Italian bread and it was a delicious, hearty meal on a cold wintery night.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2017-01-25T16:11:12.23

text:
Very tasty soup and easily adjusted to your tastes.  I didn't have zucchini or spinach on hand, but threw in a bunch of chopped fresh parsley and tomatoes.  Fresh or frozen green beans are a much better choice than canned, which are always soggy and limp.  I like the method of cooking the pasta and not having it simmer with the soup because it doesn't have a chance to get mushy.  Like other reviewers, I needed to add more liquid.  I also sprinkled cooked bacon bits on top with the fresh Parmesan cheese.  Yum!

text:
Loved this soup!  I looked at most of the Minestrone recipes on this site and decided on this one...very glad I did.  I made it as stated, except fresh green beans instead of canned, 4 cups chicken broth instead of water.  Oh, and as was on a different Minestrone recipe, a (generous!) pinch of red pepper flakes, because I put them in pretty much everything for a little kick.  It made a lot so the next day I had to add more liquid (more tomato sauce and chicken broth) because the veggies absorbed a good bit of the liquid.  I thought the guys I cook for would complain that there's no meat, but they didn't...it was very hearty and filling.  Thank you for recipe and I will make it regularly.  Super healthy too!

I made this soup for a church potluck and it was gone instantly!  Everyone loved it.  I used vegetable broth to keep this minestrone recipe vegetarian.  I also used 1 quart of tomato sauce I had put up from my garden, and 4 c vegetable broth, no water.  I chopped up some cabbage too and added that instead of spinach just because I had it on hand.  It was delicious!   P.S. My dad who barely eats anything now, really enjoyed this soup too.  Heartfelt thanks for sharing this recipe, Jamie.

This was very good.  I made it in the crock pot.  I did not saute any vegetables, just threw everything except spinach and pasta in crock pot and cooked all afternoon.  I did add a dash of chipotle tabasco, Worcestershire, extra garlic, and salt and pepper.  45 minutes before eating I added heaping cup of sea shell pasta and 1/2 bag of baby spinach.  I did not use any water, but used extra chicken broth to accommodate for the lack of liquid.

text:
This soup is delicious. I made some changes after reading other reviews here. First of all, I made the soup in the crockpot. I love the idea of putting a recipe together, and going about my day while supper is cooking. I added two cans of chicken broth, two cans of diced tomatoes, two zucchini, one yellow squash, and green beans. They all came from our garden and I had blanched and froze them, Next, I added three carrots, two stalks of celery, and one onion.A 10.5 oz bag fresh spinach,  I added a clove of garlic, and 1 tsp dried oregano, 2 tsp dried basil. It cooked low all day. An hour before eating, I added a 1/2 cup elbow macaroni . I omitted the kidney beans as my husband doesn't like them., I served a salad and grand biscuits with our meal. This recipe makes so much, my crockpot was full. We have plenty left to have again tomorrow night.

text:
I make this soup all the time. At least once a month if not more and then eat it for multiple meals, multiple days. I have been asked by many for my recipe and I always give it to them with a couple of tweaks. I use all low sodium chicken broth, no water. I substitute half of the zucchini for diced red potatoes. I take about 2 cups of the soup, both veggies and liquid and blend it up to put it back in and create a thicker base. It's so good. People love it.

This was an amazing soup. Perfect for a chilly winter night. I made a few changes based on others reviews:
*I used canelli beans and I puréed  them with a cup of the broth and added to the soup since my household is anti beans 
*I added a Parmesan cheese rind while simmering and took out before serving 
*i used white wine bc I didn't have red and it tasted fine 
* I omitted green beans 
* I made the pasta but didn't end up putting it in bc I served it with a side of crusty French bread instead 
delicious will make again

text:
This soup was amazing. I used 3 cups stock and 1 cup water. While I was chopping the veg I threw in a frozen rotisserie chicken carcass in to the canned stock. *THIS MAKES ALL THE DIFFERENCE IN THE WORLD* if you can't use homemade chicken stock, do this, you won't regret it. I also didn't have any fresh seasoning song used powdered. I took out the green beans and used cannelloni. I used only one giant onion instead of 2  and I did a mix of crookneck squash and zucchini. This is going in the repeat pile!!!!

text:
Made this soup and loved it. I pretty much followed the recipe as written with minor changes to suit my taste and based on things I had on hand. I froze some of the soup in small portion sizes for quick easy meals. The soup freezes well and did not affect the texture of the pasta or veggies. I gave some to a friend at work and she asked for the recipe...she loved the fact that the veggies were not soft and mushy but stayed barely crisp.  This is a hearty soup with good flavor - a must try soup.

text:
We LOVED how healthy and delicious this recipe is! I've made it twice in the past week. I halved the recipe each time for my small family. Made a few adjustments: not a huge fan of canned tomato paste, so I used about 2 cups of chopped tomatoes and only about 2 tablespoons of canned tomato sauce. Also didn't have oregano, so substituted some dried thyme instead, which gave it a wonderful flavour. Doubled the amount of noodles. Used no green beans and about twice the amount of kidney beans specified in the recipe. No wine. Served it with the herbed French bread from this site and it was a fantastic and very comforting meal!! Will be making this time and again.

This was a wonderful soup for a cold rainy evening. I ommited the water and substituted with using all chicken broth as the other reviewers recommended, and added some red pepper flakes to the sauteed vegetables to give the soup some kick. Beautiful flavor added by the red wine and I was able to freeze a large tupperware of leftovers!

text:
Great versital recipe. If anyone has made soup before without recipes they would know leaving out the tomato base does not make it minestrone. It makes it chicken soup.. Cracks me up how people change things so much and then rate. I have my own version of minestrone I made up long ago. I had everything on hand left over from a winter garden for this one so gave it a go. Yes, I changed vegetables for our liking. But the base was the same. Yummy it was. Similar to mine only instead of tomato sauce I use half chicken and half pasta sauce. I do think the pasta sauce makes it thicker and packs more flavor but this way is just as good and will be put in my rotation.  Minestrone is my favorite soup and I make it more then others.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
Really good soup and a lot of it! I followed the recipe exactly except that I used a crock pot. After sauteing the veggies, I dumped everything (except the noodles) in the crock pot, filled to the brim, and cooked on low for about 10 hours. Everything held up nicely, and there was a ton of broth. The fresh herbs made a big difference. For wine, I used Apothic Red, which was good in the soup and also served alongside it. I found that the soup needed a lot of extra salt to meet its potential, plus a little cayenne pepper. Otherwise pretty spot on! I used those sweet little organic carrots in mine, and they were tasty. I've been eating on this soup for days, shared several bowls with friends, and there's still a lot left.

userID:
6835921
Display Name:
Maria Velazquez
isPro:

followersCount:
1

0

7
favoritesCount:
40
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1159338.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Made as stated this is only a 2 or 3 star soup. But I managed to make it into a 4 star before my husband came home. I did tweak this recipe but only after tasting it and it didn't taste like minestrone, more like a bland tomato soup with onion. I noticed as it simmered that there wasn't going to be much liquid so I added 1 cup more broth and kept adding water as I saw fit (probably 2 more cups). Had to use a lot of salt as it lacked flavor and I am not a good enough cook to know how to use herbs or spices to add flavor to food. Way to many veggies. Love them but way way to many. I'll cut it down to half next time I try this (if I do). So finally it was done, and it was just alright, but it still lacked something. So I added lime to my dish (which I was wary of doing because I didn't know how good it would go with the Parmesan but it worked out). Ate two bowls. Husband ate without the lime and said it was ok for being my first time attempting this soup but he did eat another bowl a few hours later. 

Not sure if the servings are off or if it was the 3 extra cups of liquid added, but after 5 bowls of soup eaten, I still have over half the pot full. 

So if you live near me and want to try this soup, please come by for some.

Great base to start with. text:
This was one of the best soups I've ever made!  I was looking for a recipe to use up some ingredients that I had, so my soup wasn't 100% according to the recipe but I don't think it would matter, the base was the same.  I added a couple of Yukon Gold potatoes, peeled and cut up, about a cup of a corn/pea/carrot/green bean frozen vegetable mix instead of the can of green beans, and one whole can of white kidney beans instead of one cup red.  I omitted the red wine and used one large zucchini instead of three.  I used half of the amount called for of onion, celery and carrots.  I kept the ratio of chicken broth, water and tomato sauce.  Finally, I used whole wheat penne instead of shells, and cut them into shell-sized pieces once cooked.  We were really impressed with the results and will definitely be making it again!

Made this recipe last week.  I followed it almost exactly.  I didn't use as much garlic or onion to accommodate my own preferences, I don't like too much of those ingredients in my recipes.  This recipe did take me about an hour and a half to make which is stated in the recipe so I was warned.  It ended up tasting a bit bland. If I were to make this again, I would definitely use less tomato sauce.

country:

text:
i'm a huge fan of making soups, but as written this seemed to lean more towards a very hearty tomato flavored stew.. i cut the recipe in half and used 1/2 an onion, 1 1/2 stalks of celery, 10 baby carrots cut into matchsticks, 3 cups of chicken broth, one 8 oz can of tomato sauce, canellini beans instead of kidney, 1/2 cup of frozen green beans, probably a little more spinach than called for, added 10 oz of italian seasoning ground turkey and made little meatballs out of them, one zucchini instead of 1 1/2, doubled the pasta and used the corkscrew kind,  1 1/2 tsp italian seasoning for the oregano and basil, a smidgen of ground thyme and a dash of cayenne.. in the future i'd add the zucchini's much later as we like our veggies more crisp and by the time everything was done the zucchini's were very soft.. i will give Jamie credit as the whole point of this recipe was to incorporate more veggies into the soup and reduce the salt which canned soups are notorious for.. it may be a bit much for most people.. but you get an A for effort.. ty for a great starting point

Love this recipe. Used homemade crushed Roma tomatoes for the base, scallopini squash instead of zucchinni (needed to use it up) and pretty much followed the recipe. Made a double batch to freeze half. Used some Eden Kamut small tube noodles cooked on the side! Delicious!

Display Name:
Christy Burrows Pulley
isPro:

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2525910.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I'm about to be one of those totally annoying people who change the recipe. But here goes... I sauteed garlic and onion, then added sweet Italian sausage links. When that had cooked down for a while, I cut up the sausage with scissors then added 4 cups of chicken broth, 2 cans of Italian-style stewed tomatoes, some white wine, and let it come to a boil, then added everything else - 2 small zucchini, 1 small yellow squash, fresh basil, fresh oregano, a bag of frozen mixed veggies (corn, carrots, green beans, lima beans), a can of garbanzos, a can of kidneys, fresh kale and fresh spinach. Let it all cook down for an hour plus. When it was almost done, I realized I'd forgotten the fingerling potatoes I'd bought at the farmer's market, so I sliced them 1/4 inch and threw them into the boiling pot for 20 more minutes.

Ladled soup over big shell pasta and garnished with lots of fresh grated parm. It was to die for. 

Mmmm. Mmmm. Mmmm!

This soup is absolutely wonderful, just as good as a restaurants. text:
Such a hit! Like others, I modified to what I had on hand (used Kale instead of spinach for an extra health boost!). I also used all vegetable broth to make it 100% vegetarian. I saw one review comparing this soup to Progresso and had to laugh. If you're using mostly fresh ingredients and keep the canned ingredients simple, there is no way this recipe comes even close. Commercial canned soups are loaded with MSG and other preservatives one would never cook with in the kitchen.

This is my favorite soup.  I could eat it every day.  I used 32 oz of vegetable broth instead of water/broth.  I didn't have any zucchini, but I threw in about a cup of broccoli.  I cooked the whole thing in a crock pot on hi for about 6 hours.  It was amazing, I'll make it the same way forever.  I'm famous for my lasagna, and that's what I always make on Christmas Eve.  I had to remind people to eat the lasagna because everyone was helping themselves to a second and third helping of soup.  I served this soup, breadsticks, a simple salad and lasagna.  It was a delicious feast!

None
text:
I made this yesterday and it was fantastic. I made some minor changes- I subbed two cans of petit diced tomatoes with garlic and olive oil for the tomato sauce and I used all chicken broth instead of water. I also used an entire 9oz package of fresh spinach and threw a cup of uncooked sea shells in for the last 15 min of cooking instead of cooking separately. Oh, and I used dried herbs (half the rx amount for fresh). I left some at my parents today for them to reheat for dinner and my dad called me to tell me it was outstanding and better than carrabas minestrone that he had just had! With some tweaks to your taste, this recipe is 5 stars!!

text:
I made this today and it was a really good base recipe. I did make some minor changes. I used dried herbs rather than fresh because that's what I had. I omitted the kidney beans, zucchini, and wine just a personal preference. I added 3 red potatoes and a can of petite diced tomatoes. I also used about 2.5c vegetable broth, 1c chicken broth, and 1c water. The broth came out a little thicker then I would have liked, probly because of the potatoes but I came out delicious. I think next time I'll just cook the noodles in the soup that way they'll cook in the flavor.. I also think I'll add more seasoning next time cuz I feel like it was still missing something! But overall delicious!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was a great soup! Made enough for two dinners for 4 people and then froze the rest.  I made this the crockpot and let it cook for about 5 hours and the vegetables were tender-crisp, not over cooked like some soups can be.  I used some of the reviewers suggestions and used all chicken stock and reduced the water to 1/2 cup.  I also used 1 can of tomato sauce and 1 can of fire-roasted, diced tomatoes.  Definitely add the wine!  I sauteed the onion, carrot and celery a few minutes just to get the flavors to blend and added everything to the crockpot.  Omitted the spinach and added a can of white beans.  The spices were perfect.  This is a keeper!!

I substituted cauliflower and kale for the zucchini and spinach out of necessity, and it came out wonderful. I scooped out all the kale with whatever veggies came with it at the end and pureed it (its texture can be a bit rough), then put it back in the soup. Also used Italian-style canned tomatoes instead of tomato sauce. The entire family enjoyed it, including the 1-year-old. The taste is so hearty and wholesome.

text:
One of the few soups my husband likes is minestrone, which up until recently was courtesy of campbell's....I have tried a couple of recipes that didn't turn out so great, not enough flavor. This one is the winner, my husband will never again have minestrone from a can! Thank you Jamie! Fantastic flavor and chock full of great veggies. Changes made, I chopped the veggies smaller than suggested (personal preference) added 4 cups of chicken broth and no water, an extra can of beans (used canellini instead of kidney) and an extra can of green beans. I also used dried oregano and basil instead of fresh. Tasted great the first day so I know it will be even better tomorrow...looking forward to the leftovers.

text:
I made this 8 serving size soup after seeing this recipe.  Switched the celery & zucchinis for potatoes.  Switched the chicken broth for vegetable broth.  Cooked everything else according to the recipe.  It turned out very nice!  I made extra pasta the first day, I used it the second day, the pasta didn't go soggy and tasted fine.  I thought the soup would be too thick, but that was not the case at all.  I loved it, ate it for 2-3 meals.  I am making it again tonight for my family.  

This time I'll go with a side of bread.  With all those veggies, this is a very nutritious meal.

I can't believe it's taken me this long to write a review.  I've made this minestrone several times and every time I get asked for the recipe.  The only change I make is to add some red chili flakes (I like spice) and sometimes I add ground turkey (browned first).  I think adding turkey means this is technically no longer minestrone, but if I want all my food groups in one bowl it works for me.

text:
This is a great start for creating minestrone soup. In typical fashion, I made changes to suit our tastes. I used all vegetable broth instead of water and chicken broth (vegetarian). I used more beans, cannellini and red kidney, the entire can of both, less green beans, more spinach, no zucchini since we forgot to buy, added diced red potatoes, added about 2 extra cups of broth and 1 cup of tomato sauce. It STILL came out quite chunky and delicious. It makes a lot of soup but it only tastes better the next day. Thanks Jamie for a great recipe!

text:
Wowsers!  This is one of the most impressive-tasting recipes I've come across, but was very straightforward to make.  I followed the recipe pretty closely, except that I only had 2 cups of tomato sauce, so I added a couple of fresh diced tomatoes and a few squirts of tomato paste (was flavorful enough this way, so will be curious to see whether it is over-flavored with 4 full cups of sauce).  I also omitted the green beans and doubled the amount of spinach.  Finally, during the cooking process, I just threw some uncooked ditalini into the soup when there was about 10 mins left in the cooking process vs. cooking separately.  I thoroughly enjoyed this soup... it was so flavorful and so healthy.  Did not even need the parmesan cheese.

This was very good.  I hadn't had minestrone soup in years and for some reason got the craving.  The reason I did not give it 5 stars is because mine ended up more like a pasta dish, maybe because I used large macaroni noodles instead of the standard size.  But it was still tastey.  I used beef broth since that is what I had, and omitted the wine since I don't keep wine in the house.  A very healthy dinner and my kids loved it, and didn't complain once about all the veggies (used spinach from our garden which was very exciting, our first vegetable to be harvested this year).

region:

country:
None
text:
This is a fantastic soup! It makes so much and you can freeze the extra for later. I love this because it makes an easy pack-and-go lunch when it's sitting in the fridge.  Some changes I make: I add extra tomato sauce (whatever one Large can is) and then I also add a large can of chunks of tomatoes to add some more texture! Also, I do less water and more chicken broth for more flavor and I just add in a ton of veggies. I do add at least one yellow squash for the color, too. It doesn't seem that you can mess up this soup! I don't use pasta shells, cheese or the olive oil at the end because I think it's a hearty enough soup without the extra calories!

You don't even need another rave review, but you get it again. This was very good. I don't often get excited when I'm making something, but just putting this together was a treat to the eye. I took the liberty of using young green beans instead of canned, steaming them for five minutes before chopping to add when the canned would have gone in. Also, we already had some cooked spaghetti in the refrigerator, so I chopped the strands for the pasta portion, which may not have been as pretty, but was faithful to the flavor concept, surely. For any who are doing Weight Watcher's. This comes in at 4 points per generous serving.

text:
I have been wanting to make a homemade minestrone soup for a long time and when I found this recipe, I decided to try it. I am glad I did! This soup turned out excellent and I will definitely be making it again. I did make a few changes: used all chicken stock instead of water, added a can of diced tomatoes in addition to the tomato sauce, and I used dried spices instead of fresh. I also added some Merlot to the soup. My husband and children loved this soup. We also made our own garlic bread with mozzarella cheese toasted in the oven to dip in the soup. This will be a regular soup recipe in our home.

Excellent soup!  As others have noted, this is a wonderful base for a soup that can be adjusted based upon personal tastes and ingredients one has on hand.  I made this for a vegetarian friend, therefore substituted vegetable stock for the chicken broth and the water. Otherwise I pretty much followed the recipe and thought it was a very balanced, delicious soup!

text:
Very simple and very good.  You can obviously add & subtract and many diff. vegies as desired. I omitted the kidney beans and spinach and added fresh green beans instead of canned.  This was just b/c of what I had on hand.  Fresh gr. beans are awesome in this.  I also had to add a lot more water and therefore more spices (tried to keep same ratio).  Even though added more water I didn't feel I needed more tomato sauce.  I also cooked my pasta directly in the stew about 1/2 way through.  Delicious and will definitely make again.

text:
This was really good!  I especially loved all the fresh, chunky vegetables.  Great flavor.  Also, a really forgiving recipe because you can basically use whatever veggies you've got on hand.  I generally add stewed toms (cut up) and a bit of Worcestershire.  And serve the noodles separate by letting people add them to their individual bowls.  That way the noodles don't get too mushy in the leftovers!  This is a great recipe for easy-going rainy days. :)

userID:
2526861
Display Name:
Sarah Stanford
isPro:
False
followersCount:
3

16

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2969907.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Mmm, good soup!  I used dried Great Northern beans instead of canned kidney beans--1/2 cup, soaked for about six hours.  After I sauteed the veggies, I added the soaked beans and four cups of water, and let it bubble away until the beans softened--a little over an hour.  I did end up having to add about three more cups of water to keep it from getting too thick.  Once the beans were soft, I added one can diced tomatoes, one chopped fresh tomato, one 8oz. can of tomato sauce, the zucchini and spinach (left out the green beans), two chicken bouillon cubes, white wine, and dried herbs, and simmered for another 45 minutes.  Final result is wonderful.  I will come back to this recipe often.

text:
Great stuff, easy to make, and yields a ton of very chunky soup.  I ran largely with the recipe as written but cut the sodium way down: Herb-ox instead of real broth, no salt added tomato sauce and beans, no cheese or salt - added a smidge of cayenne to add a little zing and cover for the lack of salt.  Followed the other comments and used ditalini instead of shells.  Turned out fantastic.  Will add more broth and some crushed tomatoes next time and maybe some cabbage.

Loved this recipe. I made half of the recipe and it still made a huge amount. But that is great-packed for lunch the next day for myself and my boyfriend.  I did not have oregano and basil so I used an Italian seasoning packet and we are cabbage fans so I used cabbage instead of spinach. Did not have fresh carrots so I used canned sliced carrots. Came out wonderfully! Will make again and again. Very filling and hearty soup.

Pretty darn good! So easy to make and it tastes just like the stuff you would get in a can without all the nasty extras. I sauteed the onion, garlic, carrots and celery then put everything into the slow cooker on low for the day. I used homemade chicken stock and didn't add the spinach.  I also competely forgot to add the kidney beans which I only realised when we were eating!  Served with Jo's Rosemary Bread from this site.

This is a fantastic recipe! I make this all the time especially in the winter and the great thing is that you really can throw in any vegetables that are in season and it tastes great!  Sometimes I leave the pasta out to cut out the carbs.  This soup also freezes really well... since it makes so much I freeze it in individual servings and re-heat for lunch!  Also if fresh herbs arent available or I dont have them I use the basil, oregano tomato sauce which also tastes great!

text:
This soup is so healthy and delicious. I gave it 4 stars because I made many modifications, although I'm sure it would have been good anyway. I used 1 (29 oz) can of concentrated crushed tomatoes, 1 (28 oz) can of regular crushed tomatoes. I also added a lot more garlic than called for. I used one full can each of chicken broth & vegetable broth instead of the water and dried oregano because I didn't find fresh at the store. I used dry kidney beans (pre-soaked) and fresh green beans instead of canned. I used 2 yellow squash and 2 zucchinis, whole wheat rotini (store didn't have seashell pasta).

I've been making this soup for years and am just getting around to rating it... I call this soup "garbage soup" mostly because I add just about any veggies I have in the fridge.  I also sometimes start off the soup by frying up some crumbled italian sausage and then sauting my veggies in the fat.  I have added canned corn, black beans, white beans...if I have it, it generally goes in. I always use italian seasoning though instead of the recommended seasonings.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was so great.  Let simmer for about 1.5 hours and came out perfect.  Made so much for the two of us that I have tons frozen and lots of leftovers.  Delicious and Inexpensive to make! Edited: I have made this many, many times since my initial review.  It is fail proof, and everyone loves it.  The recipe as-is is VERY thick and I always felt like I wanted more liquid.  These are my changes: 2 zuchinni and 2 squash, 8 cups chicken broth and omit the water, 1 can crushed tomatoes, and 3 cans tomato sauce.  Seems like a lot, but it made it the perfect consistency.   I have made it with both fresh and dried spices, and it's well worth the effort to use fresh.  Sometimes I add pasta, and sometimes I don't, but either way, it's great.  It is ALWAYS best the day after (which makes it perfect for pot lucks) it is cooked.  Have fun--you really can't go wrong with this recipe!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was a great recipe. I have the recipe for this soup from a well known italian restaurant in my city, and this was better, I think.  The fresh herbs and spinach made a huge difference.  I made it yesterday, had it for dinner, and then froze the leftovers in freezer bags to use later.  I ended up giving most of it away to friends and had it with a couple friends for lunch today, and they raved about it.  Before freezing, I added the noodles and extra water, about 1/2c per gallon freezer bag, and I was afraid this would affect the taste, but it didn't.  I gave it 4 stars because overall, it could use a little stronger flavor, and it could use a little extra broth(very hearty and thick).  However, it really was good, easy to modify(flavor), and easy to make with my 3 year old daughter.  Good job!

text:
A huge success!  I didn't have any tomato sauce or v8 juice, so I ended up using a can of diced tomatoes and 4 ripe vine-ripe fresh tomatoes.  I added worcestershire sauce to add depth as it was mentioned in another post and it really helped.  I used 2 zucchinis and 1 yellow onion.  I also added some peas and potatoes instead of pasta.  I agree with others that this is a very good base recipe that you can play with.  The recipe did make a lot of soup.  It tastes much better the next day.

text:
It's become a staple in my house. We always seem to serve it on special occasions, so my kids call it "Celebration Soup".
Like everyone else, I've modified what I add - use fresh instead of canned green beans, not as many carrots, but I add asparagus, and veggie stock instead of chicken broth.
The fresh basil and oregano are key to the recipe - don't use dried.

text:
I must admit to being a bit nervous after adding the veg concoction to the pot.  It was just so chunky and even after letting it simmer for an hour, the veggies were still a bit crunchy.  In the end, this turned out to be one of the best tasting soups I've ever tried from this site - but not without a few alterations.  I did end up allowing the soup to simmer for an additional hour and 20 mins longer than the recipe indicated.  I also added another can of chx broth ( plus a tad more oregano and basil) and 1tsp of garlic powder.   Deeelissh!

text:
Good minestrone. You could add just about any vegetable to this. I used fresh green beans (instead of canned), tomato paste (instead of tomato sauce), vegetable broth (instead of chicken broth), and 1/2 cup spagetti sauce. Turned out delcious. Make sure you add baby spinach, it cooks down and tastes yummy. Oh, you can't hardly taste the garlic, so if you love garlic, at least double the amount.
